The deaf community have concerns about implanting deaf children according to decisions made by their parents. The main controversy is about implanting children who cannot decide for themselves. The community are also concerned that parents may put too much focus on the strategies supporting implants and insufficient focus on supporting strategies around children learning AUSLAN and other communication strategies. They are also concerned that funding and resources are being diverted away from services for deaf children and adults and into new and expensive technologies. I ask the government to listen to and work with the deaf community about these concerns.

Cochlear implants and replacement parts are covered by the government via Australian Hearing Services for children up to the age of 21 years. I want to focus on the issues for adults who choose cochlear implants. Firstly, adults who do not have private health cover generally get their upgrades and replacement speech processors through hospital inpatient services. Secondly, adults who have private health cover are covered for upgrades and replacement speech processors by their private health fund. I note with alarm the recommendations of the Private Health Industry Medical Devices Expert Committee to remove speech processors from appendix A of schedule 5 of the National Health Act 1953. What would that mean? It would mean that private health insurance companies would no longer be required to reimburse recipients of cochlear implants for the cost of upgrading or replacing their speech processors, which are the machines that are worn externally by a person with a cochlear implant. These processors need to be upgraded for a variety of reasons. The most common reasons occur when the processors become technologically obsolete or when they are worn out through damage or wear and tear.

Why did PHIMDEC recommend that the upgrades be removed? The argument is that upgrades and replacements be removed from schedule 5 on the basis that they occur in an outpatient setting rather than as part of an episode of hospital treatment. Medicare covers the original cochlear implant as it occurs as part of an episode of hospital treatment. However, under the new arrangements proposed by the minister, the upgrades may be covered by private health funds through their ancillary tables. That can put people out of pocket, as we all know that ancillary items, even with top cover, will not cover an $8,000 bill. Although PHIMDEC has recommended their delisting, the decision to move on that advice has been deferred. However, this has put the issue into limbo, and people who might be directly affected by the decision to remove the items from the schedule are extremely concerned.

Some people in the deaf community are asking, `Are the government and the committee going to organise some community consultation, especially with the deaf community, about the implications of this decision to delist upgrades and replacement processors?' I ask the government to take this concern on board and to work with the deaf community for a mutually beneficial outcome. I ask also that the government provide a telephone typewriter for every parliamentarian's office to improve deaf people's access to their members of parliament and senators. It is very badly missed in our repertoire of equipment provided by the parliament and by the Department of Finance and Administration.

talk.start.para: —As chair of the health and ageing committee, I too am very happy to speak on this motion on cochlear implants in Deaf-Blind Awareness Week. The invention and development of cochlear implants, or bionic ears as they are sometimes called, has for many people been a modern miracle. A cochlear implant is an artificial hearing device designed to enable deaf people to hear by electrically stimulating nerves inside the inner ear.

speech.para: An essential component is the speech processor, which is worn on the body, often in the person's pocket. The function of the speech processor is to convert the electrical impulses from a microphone into a signal or set of signals which the implant converts into recognisable words or sounds. As with so many of the inventions and developments within the area of health, the monetary cost of cochlear implants and the associated speech processors is high. Private health insurance funds are required to fully fund cochlear implants and speech processors for privately insured patients. This is guaranteed by the fact that they are included in the Commonwealth prosthesis schedule under the National Health Act 1953.

As the member for Griffith stated in his motion, the Private Health Industry Medical Devices Expert Committee has recommended that speech processors be removed from the schedule. The reason for this view is that speech processors are not provided as part of hospital treatment. Had the opposition supported the government's attempts to provide health insurance cover to outpatient services, this would not be an issue, but we all know that the opposition would rather engage in scare campaigns than improve health services to the Australian people.

The member for Griffith would be aware that, despite the committee's recommendation, the government has not removed speech processors from the schedule. The member may also know that there is currently a review of the private health insurance regulation under way and that the government has stated that there will be no decision on the committee's recommendations until the finalisation of this review. Whatever the outcome of the review, Australian Hearing Services, under the department of health and family services, will continue to provide replacement cochlear speech processors to every Australian under the age of 21 who is in need of such devices. I am advised that there is currently no waiting list for this service. Families can rest assured that the Howard government is committed to ensuring the equitable provision of hearing services and devices to the hearing impaired.

Government members are well aware of the importance of cochlear implants. On a previous occasion, the member for Mitchell spoke about the great work being undertaken by the St Gabriel's School for Hearing Impaired Children in his electorate and the importance of providing children with effective hearing devices as early as possible so that they gain maximum advantage. The members for Leichhardt and Longman have also spoken on this, and the government will continue to provide cochlear implants and speech processors to all Australian children who need them. This commitment is not dependent on any review or any decision of the committee. It is a non-negotiable commitment to Australian families.

Many in this House would already know that the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman supports the continued full coverage of cochlear implants and speech processors, and that several funds have already stated their support for this. There is no need for this motion, other than to satisfy the opposition's need to scare people.

talk.start.para: —I strongly support the motion moved by the member for Griffith, Mr Kevin Rudd. My electorate of Lowe is home to a significant number of disability services for the deaf and for people with other hearing disabilities. I am indebted for the advice given to me by one of my constituents, Mr Peter Kerley, of the Deafness Council of New South Wales Inc. The Deafness Council is an organisation that has led the way in advocating both technological and non-technocentric solutions for meeting the communications needs of people with a deafness disability. The Deafness Council advises me that there are about 2,000 Australian cochlear implantees, and there are 900 children who are eligible for cochlear implants. I am advised that a surgical cochlear implant costs approximately $40,000. This cost is covered almost entirely by Medicare and private insurance. The total cost is in the order of $18 million, with a cost recycling every eight to 10 years. The costs include the surgery, the speech processor upgrade and repeat surgery at approximately 15 years.

speech.para: That being said, a more typical profile of a cochlear based technocentric solution for hearing restoration may include up to six operations and up to 12 speech processor upgrades over the whole life of the person. I urge this House to reject the recommendations of the Private Health Industry Medical Devices Expert Committee to withdraw private health funding for upgrades and replacements for cochlear implants. If the government decides to accept the committee's recommendations, the government will be succumbing to the corporate world by acceding to the desire of the private health insurance lobby to socialise the losses and costs of these medical upgrades and replacement procedures.

Children growing up with these implants require further surgery and replacements. The child turned adult will remain dependent on that cochlear technology. The child requires listening skills to obtain and retain employment and for the basic necessities of life. You cannot give the child a cochlear implant and then make it unaffordable by denying upgrades in later life. I ask the committee and this House: has the committee considered all of the consequences of transferring the burden of the cost of a speech processor onto the taxpayer, rather than through private health insurance, by simply calling it a prosthesis?

Prospective consumers of further cochlear upgrades will have an overhead of approximately $3,500 per year per implanted person. If this expense is not compensated through private health insurance, most will find the technology unaffordable. The consequence of this will be that these people, for the most part, will be unemployed or unemployable with a concomitant increase in social security costs. Either way, the government, the taxpayer and—most importantly—the person with the deafness disability lose. It would appear that the government has created a smokescreen to hide the fact that it has capitulated to the private health insurance industry. I certainly hope not.

Finally, I turn to the issue of solutions that will keep cochlear implantees within the insurance bounds of private health insurance policy. I recall a few years ago the Commonwealth government introducing a system to compensate health insurers who had insurance risk exposure from having too many elderly clients. So I ask, in anticipation of the costs and the numbers of existing and potential cochlear implants candidates being established, that a similar system of cost spreading among private health insurers for those using cochlear implants also be considered. I condemn the committee's recommendation and support Mr Rudd's very worthy motion.

talk.start.para: —Cochlear implants consist of three linked components: a microphone, placed behind the ear; a speech processor, which can be worn on the belt and which converts sound to electrical signals; and a surgically implanted receptor, which stimulates neurons in the cochlea. This is an Australian innovation and it is a marvel. There are figures which now show that 80 per cent of deaf people can get improvement from a cochlear implant, and children who are born deaf may be able to hear because of this technology. Cochlear speech processors are included in the 8,900 items listed on the prostheses schedule under the National Health Act. The government requires private health funds to pay 100 per cent of the cost of these items. Some items on the prostheses schedule cost thousands of dollars—several items cost more than $15,000 and one item costs $40,000.

speech.para: What this motion is all about—and I believe this is an unnecessary motion—is the all too familiar scaremongering by members on the other side of the House. At present, private health insurance funds are required to pay for cochlear speech processors listed on the prostheses schedule. They will be required to pay for the cochlear speech processors for the foreseeable future. I find the motion by the member for Griffith puzzling. As technology has improved, some items that were an inpatient procedure are now an outpatient procedure. That is what we are actually debating today. What has happened is that procedures that were normally done in hospital, which were covered by private health insurance, are now done as outpatient procedures, which are not covered by private health insurance. Cochlear speech processors are one of these procedures. Private health insurance funds are only allowed to cover items which are provided in hospital. The reason the cochlear speech processors and other items have been listed for review is that the prostheses schedule is for items provided in hospital.

If the opposition are suggesting that they would like to see private health funds cover outpatient procedures, I am sure the government would welcome that. In 1998, the government introduced legislation to allow health funds to cover outpatient procedures; the Labor Party voted against that legislation. Instead of just scaremongering, if the opposition are concerned about continued access to cochlear speech processors by private health insurance funds, then they will support the reintroduction of a bill to allow private health insurance to cover outpatient procedures.

As previous speakers have said, at the moment there is a review into private health insurance regulation, which will include the topic of whether to fund these items. The Minister for Health and Ageing has said that no decision will be made, pending the outcome of this review. She has also said that children and young adults under 21 will automatically be covered by Australian Hearing Services. But more than that, the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman has stated that, as the funds have always provided for cochlear speech processors, they should continue to do so. The Private Health Insurance Ombudsman has committed to working with the funds to continue funding these procedures. The funds have also indicated that they are likely to keep them on. So, at the moment, this rests on the goodwill of the funds and also on the pressure coming from the government and the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman. But, if you want to stop this sort of situation in the future, you should support our legislation, which allows for private health insurance to be used to cover outpatient procedures, because, as technology changes and as practice changes, that is what is happening. If the member for Griffith is serious about wanting private health insurance funds to continue to provide benefits to cover cochlear speech processors, he will support the government in allowing funds to cover outpatient procedures—or is he just scaremongering?

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to support the member for Griffith, and my other Labor colleagues, in speaking on this motion about cochlear implants. As someone who knows personally how disabling it is to suffer hearing problems, I have much sympathy for the deaf, and especially for young people who are deaf. As we have heard from others, the cochlear implant—or bionic ear, as it is popularly known—is an Australian invention. It is another example of Australian ingenuity which has the potential to assist thousands of people in the world. Unlike some other Australian inventions which have been ignored in this country, this invention was picked up and developed here—an Australian company dominates the market for its production. How ironic that we have an Australian invention, an Australian product and a market for the product but that we have a real problem in making the product affordable for those who want it.

speech.para: There are a number of players involved in this issue: the government; Australian Hearing Services, which is funded by the government; Cochlear Ltd, who are the manufacturers; the private health industry; the Private Health Industry Medical Devices Expert Committee, which was appointed by the previous minister for health to assist with determining items for listing on the schedule for private health benefit funding of prostheses; and—everyone seems to have forgotten—those who are profoundly deaf, who benefit from the fitting and maintenance of cochlear implants.

It seems that there are real anomalies in the way that cochlear implants are treated by the various players. Australian Hearing Services provides them, but has limited funds provided by the government to do this and suggests people contact Cochlear Ltd or their private health fund. Cochlear Ltd advises people to lobby the government; private health funds also suggest lobbying the government. Meanwhile, the profoundly deaf are waiting for help, and you cannot blame them for thinking that they are being given the run-around. Imagine how distressing it is, especially for those who have young children, who cannot understand why they are unable to access the product that will make a difference to their lives.
Gayle and Gary Wharton wrote to me about the circumstances of their son Matthew. They wrote:

quote.para: An apparent loophole in the current Schedule 5 legislation shouldn't be the reason why private health funds be allowed to reneg on their responsibilities.

speech.para: They continue:

quote.para: They—

speech.para: that is, the government and the funds—

quote.para: seem to be focusing on informing people that the upgrades/replacements will continue through Australian Hearing, but as you are no doubt aware, this ceases at the age of 21 and doesn't start again unless you are on an aged pension or a disability pension.

speech.para: They go on to say:

quote.para: I don't hear our Government making any mention of what happens to the cochlear implant recipients after the age of 21, or are they presuming that hearing impaired people won't be able to find a job and will go on a disability pension. Matthew, for one, can't wait to find a job and be independent. How independent can he hope to be, when on a 21 year old's wage, he'll have to be saving up for his next speech processor upgrade so he can hear better?

speech.para: I sympathise with them. To reiterate the situation, earlier this year it seemed that private health companies were no longer required to reimburse recipients of these implants for the cost of upgrading or replacing their speech processors which are worn externally. Recipients who were privately insured could claim the cost of a new processor but not the cost of upgrades or replacements. This is where a big problem arises. The processors need to be upgraded or replaced after a certain time. The initial processors do not last forever. To make it even more complicated, it would seem that the reason given for why the upgrades or replacements were not to be covered was that they did not fit the legislative definition of what should be supported. That is hardly surprising when you consider that the legislation predates the technology of cochlear implants. I am sure it was not the intention of the drafters of the original legislation that such devices would not be supported.

Fortunately, this unsatisfactory situation has been recognised. I am pleased to note that the current minister for health has deferred reaching a decision on whether speech processors are to be removed from the list of items for which benefits are payable. I can only hope that this is a good sign but, after hearing what the previous government speaker said, I am not quite sure about that. I hope that the minister is listening to the needs of the cochlear implant community and that she will see that the replacement processors remain on the ancillary tables of the private health funds for the sake of the profoundly deaf, and especially children, who hope that they will be able to progress through life and work with the ability to hear. I hope that we have heard what those children have had to say today and that they will be able to get some relief soon. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Griffith for raising an extremely important issue of the status of speech processors for cochlear implants and the possible delisting of processors from schedule 5. In April 2001 the Private Health Insurance Medical Devices Expert Committee, PHIMDEC, recommended the removal of replacement speech processors from schedule 5 of the National Health Act 1953. The removal of replacement speech processors from schedule 5 will allow private health insurance companies to cease reimbursement to the recipients of cochlear implants for the cost of upgrading or replacing their externally worn speech processors. It should be noted that Cochlear Ltd's new processor is not listed because it has not yet been assessed. The cost of these speech processors can be up to $8,000. Children under 21 years of age who are not privately insured can access the replacement speech processors through Australian Hearing Services, who provide replacement processors free of charge. Australian Hearing Services are funded for $1.4 million over four years to 2004-05. They have a large pool of funds up to $28 million that they can direct by internal decision making. The $1.4 million is allocated to fund upgrades and damaged or lost processors.

speech.para: Australian Hearing Services anticipate increased demand for their free service in the event of the removal of replacements from the schedule. PHIMDEC has based its possible withdrawal on targeting prosthetic items in the schedule that would not be implanted during an episode of hospital treatment. These speech processors are replaced in an outpatients setting, whereas the initial processor is provided as part of the surgical in-patient management and would normally be covered by state or private funds. As previous speakers have said, this discussion has been deferred pending further negotiations. No action will be undertaken until this review is completed, and certainly no change will occur before February 2003. The Ombudsman, as mentioned, vows to pursue the funds to keep processors on their list of prosthetic items. I am hoping that this and other pressures on the funds will assist them in seeing the wisdom of not deleting the processors from the list of approved prosthetic items. There are approximately 1,000 cochlear implant recipients under the age of 21 who would be covered regardless of what the funds decide.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be an order of the day for the next sitting. The honourable member for Moore will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—I move:

motion.para: That this House:

speech.para: (1) endorses actions taken by the Australian Government to improve the spread of share ownership in Australia and to make shares available to Australians who had not previously owned shares; and
(2) deplores actions that have been taken which limit the spread of shares more generally to all Australians.

This motion embraces two concepts: first, the motion endorses those actions taken by the government which increase share ownership, and it involves looking at the essential reforms which have been undertaken, the impact generally of those reforms and, specifically and importantly, the beneficiaries; second, the motion deplores the actions which have been taken to limit the spread of share ownership in Australia, particularly in relation to the sale of Telstra and, more generally, in relation to share ownership across the country.

In looking at the actions that the government has taken, we must first look at the reforms. The Howard government has introduced substantial reforms designed to encourage more Australians to take up share ownership. There have been five principal actions taken to date: first, we have halved the rate of capital gains tax for individuals. Second, we have introduced rollover relief so that shares can be exchanged for shares without triggering a capital gains tax event, which is very important in the case of takeovers and for small businesses. Third—and this is an issue which came up in question time today—we have funded the abolition of stamp duties on listed shares and other quoted securities. Fourth—and this goes to the heart of the government's actions—the Howard-Costello government has offered public equity in 49.9 per cent of Telstra despite the opposition of the Labor Party. Fifth, we have encouraged employee share ownership by doubling the tax exemption discount on employee share arrangements which, in effect, encourages employees to take shares in those companies for which they work—this is participation at the heart of the economic entity for which individuals work.

More significantly, though, the question is: what is the impact of these reforms on share ownership within Australia? It is a very interesting outcome. The reforms have seen the Australian rate of share ownership rise to the highest in the Western world. The Australian Stock Exchange assesses that the direct rate of share ownership in Australia has increased from 20.6 per cent of Australian adults in 1997 to approximately 41 per cent by 2000—a doubling in the rate of share ownership over three years. Similarly, the rate of the combined direct and indirect level of ownership of shares within the community has risen from 34 per cent in 1997 to over 52 per cent at present. When we compare that with overseas levels, we see there is direct share ownership in Australia of almost 41 per cent; the USA, 32 per cent; New Zealand, 31 per cent; Canada, 26 per cent; Germany, 13 per cent. This level of ownership equates to over 5.7 million Australians having a direct interest in shares and listed securities and over 7.4 million Australians having indirect share ownership.

Of all of the initiatives, perhaps the most significant in encouraging first share owners was the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, which brought approximately 560,000 Australians into the share market for the first time. Similarly, the sale of the second tranche of Telstra introduced more than 300,000 first-time share owners into the practice and process of owning shares, with a direct hold over capital which is part of the stock market. In the years since 1997, over 2.9 million Australians have entered into the share market for the first time—the greatest rate of growth in share ownership in Australian history. In the six years since the government was elected it has had a profound effect on the level of share ownership.

An important question is: who are the beneficiaries? Women, the poor, and rural communities have proportionately benefited more than any other group. The FinancialReview of 9 February 2000 confirmed that, after historically lagging in share ownership, share ownership by women is now growing at the same rate as that of the male community, although of course there is more which still needs to be done. Similarly, the level of direct share ownership among low-income households earning less than $30,000 has now reached over 22 per cent—lower than it should be but much higher than it was. Thirdly, with regard to rural communities, through the sale of Telstra there has been an equalisation of the share ownership ratios between city and country. That divide between city and country is breaking down. Now, almost 39 per cent of rural adults have direct ownership of shares, up from 28 per cent in 1999.

What do we see in relation to the actions which have been taken to limit the spread of share ownership? The starting point is remembering that 860,00 first-time share owners have come into the market as a result of the sale of Telstra. I am happy to say that—as the register shows—I myself am one of those owners of shares in Telstra. In January 2001, the member for Werriwa produced a five-point plan for increasing share ownership, which by this year had become a 12-point plan. What do we see? We see that, of all the policies that the Labor Party held at the last election, the only policy which they said would be maintained, no matter what, is the decision to oppose the further public float of a telecommunications company. The government's position is very clear: if, and only if, there is improvement in the rural services to an acceptable level, then we will consider it.

But the Labor Party have a five-point plan for Telstra. The first is that they opposed the sale which allowed 860,00 first-time share holders into the market. The second is that they now want to asset-strip Telstra. The member for Melbourne wants to strip the retail and growth services from the basic business, which, one, destroys revenue, two, destroys production and, three, leads to the third part of their plan, albeit inadvertently. As Telstra officials themselves have said, it would destroy shareholder value to the level of up to $1 per share if they were to hive off the network from the services into separate companies, as they have already discussed. The fourth point is that they want to muffle the critics. The Labor Party have accused John Stanhope from Telstra of deceiving the Senate. Fifth, we see in today's paper that they feign victimisation when their bullyboy tactics rebound on them. The member for Melbourne complains that `Telstra threatens to sue Tanner'—an article in today's Australian. It is very interesting, though: he has privilege in this place, and outside of this place there is a very clear defence against defamation; it is called truth—so he has nothing to worry about if he adheres to the laws of defamation.

What are the opposition's share ownership policies? I am the first to appreciate new and valuable ideas, and I am certainly open to them. But, given their track record of opposing the single most significant spread of share ownership throughout Australia, the idea that they are now trumpeting spreading share ownership—despite opposing any further sale of Telstra or the expansion of the principal means of bringing shares to ordinary Australians—is a little like Henry VIII espousing family values after the fact; it sounds good but it is just not credible.

We see from them that they have three key ideas. The first is to increase home ownership for low-income earners, yet we already have a first home owners scheme and we already have some of the lowest interest rates in the last 30 years. At the same time, they oppose the principal means of achieving those interest rates: debt retirement. They propose a nest egg account, yet they criticise the baby bonus. They propose a first share owners scheme, yet at the same time they oppose the principal means of delivering those shares. Very simply, I urge this House to deplore the 1940s-style policies that the state not the individual should own shares, and I urge the House to support policies which have doubled direct share ownership in Australia, added almost three million first-time share owners and benefited women, the poor, and rural communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—Let me congratulate the member for Flinders on the impressive start that he has made to his parliamentary career. He is that a rarity on the government benches: a member who is actually interested in new ideas and a genuine public policy debate. He does not seem to have a fetish about trade unions or other community based organisations, so I welcome the arrival of the member for Flinders and the interest that he has taken in public policy issues. But in this case I cannot support his motion. It does, however, give me an opportunity to talk about Labor's approach to economic ownership and to contrast it with the government's limited public policy approach.

speech.para: It seems to me that the government has what might be depicted as a supply-side approach to ownership: that is, privatise government assets and make the shares available on the stock market. This does not mean that people necessarily have the resources or the capacity to buy the shares. Demand-side policies are also important—policies that help low- to middle-income Australians to access share equity assets and to do so in all companies, not just privatised ones. There are many companies in this nation and on our stock market that have never been privatised. Privatisation is not in the vanguard or the mainstream of economic ownership concerns. The most important thing to do is to have demand-side policies in place that help low- to middle-income Australians access the share market.

That is the difference. The government, at the end of the day, favours a small ownership tent; an ownership tent that is restricted to those who currently own shares; an ownership tent that is restricted to those who currently have the resources to participate in these economic opportunities. In contrast, Labor support the big tent of economic ownership; ownership for all; asset accumulation for 100 per cent of Australians. The member for Flinders is patting himself on the back about 55 per cent of Australians owning shares. From the Labor Party perspective, that is inadequate. We want 100 per cent of Australians to enjoy the benefits of substantial asset accumulation and economic ownership. This represents the application of traditional Labor values to a new economic reality. Increasingly, people see themselves not just as workers but as owners. We want to extend that process so that all Australians, not a small tent but a big tent of Australians, can access the ownership revolution.

Indeed, there has been a revolution, a revolution commenced by Labor governments in decades gone by. It was the education reforms of the Whitlam government in the 1970s that, for the first time, gave working families in this country access to human capital—access to higher education skills and qualifications. That was followed by the reforms of Paul Keating as Treasurer in the 1980s, reforms that opened up the Australian economy to capital accumulation and the start up of a mammoth number of small businesses. Keating deregulated the financial system so that working families who had accumulated skills and qualifications could use those skills to set up their own business and access the real economy—to access real and lasting economic ownership. It will be the role of the next Labor government to foster further mobility to ensure that working people continue to climb the ladder of economic ownership and opportunity. Our historic role in this parliament is to put more rungs on the ladder of opportunity and ownership. We did it in the seventies in education reform; we did it in the eighties with economic reform; we will do it under the next Labor government with these substantial economic ownership strategies.

I would maintain that, at the end of the day, economic mobility equals social justice. Social justice is all about the control of assets: the control and ownership of financial capital, human capital, social capital. The historic mission of our side of politics is to make those benefits available to all. Ownership for all is a great summary of the historical Labor mission. It is an equalising force. In fact, it is the most equalising force in our society.

Recently, NATSEM produced statistics about wealth inequality in Australia. This is a real bell ringer. NATSEM showed that if you take out the superannuation money— superannuation money put in by the last Labor government—then in fact wealth inequality in Australia had increased over the last 15 years. But if you put the super-annuation reforms back into the equat-ion, against all the international trends wealth inequality in Australia had not moved over the last 15 years. This is such a stunning conclusion. If you want a fairer society, if you want better access and inequality in this country, you need to give working people access to assets and ownership. `Ownership for all' is the headline direction for a fairer society.

The member for Flinders was kind enough to mention my discussion paper on this subject, and indeed it does point to new ways of furthering Labor's historical goal. Many of the ideas in the discussion paper are new to Australian policy, that is true—especially matched savings accounts, nest egg accounts, lifelong learning accounts and new forms of community ownership. In large part, this explains the media's response to the discussion paper, a response which focused almost exclusively on the first share ownership scheme. Journalists are more comfortable with the things they already know about: in this case, comparing the idea of first share ownership to the first home owners schemes that have operated in Australia for many decades. While grateful for the coverage of this policy option, it must be said that this is not Labor's highest priority for extending access to share equity assets. As I explained at the time of the launch, our priorities are in this order: first, extending the success and adequacy of Australia's superannuation scheme; second, extending the reach and significance of employee share ownership plans; third, creating nest egg accounts so that all young Australians can start their adult lives with an endowment or nest egg of financial investments; and, finally, directing share ownership for those who have not been able to access the share market in the past.

Our position is clear: Labor want to give all Australians access to the benefits of economic ownership. We believe in assets for all and that share equities are a crucial part of the ownership agenda. We have four options for share market access under consideration as part of Labor's policy review. I also note that the economic ownership discussion paper made no mention of direct share ownership as a solution to poverty—rather, emphasis is given to programs that assist poor people to save for home ownership and their children's education.

In the United States, these programs are known as matched savings accounts, and they are having a lot of success in breaking the poverty cycle and lifting people out of welfare dependency. Matched savings accounts should be thought of as a system of parallel accounts. If a poor family uses the first account to save $300 per annum—just $6 per week—that amount will be matched by non-government organisations, financial institutions and government financial sources in a second account. In the United States, the average rate of matching is two for one. The $300 that is saved in the first account becomes $900, but the significance is that the second account can only be accessed if the medium-term savings target of the family is reached in the first account. In the United States, poor families are saving effectively for housing deposits and the education of their children. The American demonstration projects have a 67 per cent success rate at the American poverty line. That is well below Australian poverty calculations and measurements.

How is the saving process facilitated in the United States among these poor families? That is achieved by a high level of rearrangement of the household budget. I like to think of these matched savings accounts as giving poor families an alternative to gambling. The matched savings accounts hold out a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, but the family must dedicate itself to that purpose over a two-, three- or even four-year period, saving in the first account to get to a certain saving target to buy a home, to educate their children or to bring learning materials into the home, and then the matching in the second account comes into play. That is when they are able to access the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. This is a much superior process and more socially useful than the gambling alternative of trying to reach the pot of gold at the club on a poker machine or down at the track on a Saturday afternoon. I congratulate Foresters ANA for their preliminary matched savings account scheme that is operating in Brisbane. I look forward to the member for Ryan—a Brisbane member—talking about this successful scheme and I also congratulate the ANZ Bank on the interest it has shown in matched savings accounts.

The other Labor initiative I would like to talk about is nest egg accounts. These aim to create a savings vehicle for low- to middle-income families so that they can more effectively provide for the future of their children. Governments supply account seed funding for newborn children plus incentives for families to contribute their own resources over time. Through the power of compound interest, the nest egg or endowment is available at the age of 18, giving young people a flying start to their adult lives, and they can invest this money in education, housing or small business start ups.

Wealthy families, of course, have always provided an inheritance for their children. I would argue that, unless the welfare state replicates this process, it is not possible to break the intergenerational cycle of wealth inequality in Australia. In effect, nest egg accounts take Labor's successful superannuation principles and apply them to the other end of the cycle.

How might such a scheme operate in Australia? This is, of course, subject to Labor policy research and part of our overall policy review process, but I expect that my friend and colleague the member for Gellibrand will provide some more detail about these nest egg accounts and, in particular, about the exciting way in which they provide young Australians with adult resources for the future, treating young people as they would treat themselves—as adults who want real resources and assets with which they can make their way in the adult world. It is a good initiative, and we will hear much more about this— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise today to support the motion moved by my friend and colleague the member for Flinders. For the benefit of the House, I might take a moment to repeat the motion. It states:

motion.para: That this House:

speech.para: (1) endorses actions taken by the Australian Government to improve the spread of share ownership in Australia and to make shares available to Australians who had not previously owned shares; and
(2) deplores actions that have been taken which limit the spread of shares more generally to all Australians.

I compliment the member for Flinders for coming up with such an important motion. It is important that the government continues to improve the spread of share ownership in Australia. The opportunity to own shares is about giving people the opportunity to have a stake in their country's prosperity and institutions. It is important that we also encourage people to invest in our nation. By doing this, we can only enhance the stability and growth of important and significant Australian companies.

The policy of increasing share ownership has never been taken seriously by the opposition, although I must acknowledge that there was some interest from the member for Werriwa. I take this opportunity to compliment the member for Werriwa for being a thinking member of the opposition frontbench. I even concede that also to the member for Gellibrand. Not too many members opposite are thinking members, but I acknowledge the members for Werriwa and Gellibrand as being two thinking members of the opposition frontbench. Whether the ideas have any resonance with the Australian people is another question, and we will soon find out about that.

The Labor Party's policy initiative on this front is pretty limited. I might just take this opportunity to mention what the Australian Financial Review said about the ideas of the member for Werriwa. On the weekend of 8 to 9 June 2002, it stated:

quote.para: Mark Latham came up with a pretty whacky idea last month. He wants the Nanny State to help the poor buy $1,000 worth of shares.

speech.para: If the Financial Review thinks the idea is pretty wacky, I am sure many others will think that as well. Those on this side of the parliament think that the member for Werriwa has a lot of ideas and most of them are pretty wacky. If the Labor Party wanted to promote share ownership, it would support this government's position on the privatisation of Telstra. The selling of Telstra shares was the largest offering of shares to the Australian public and the largest opportunity people have had to take out share ownership. The Labor Party was opposed to that and it is still opposed to it. It is time it moved with the times, because the Australian people support it and Labor would do itself a great service if it supported it. The opposition does not have much credibility on this issue, because who sold the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas? The opposition is now against selling Telstra. The Australian people will remember that, and it is important to mention that.

During the 1990s the proportion of Australians owning shares exploded from 20 per cent to as much as 43 per cent. This trend can be attributed to a number of things: the increase in retirement savings through compulsory superannuation, public floats that enticed first-time shareholders into the market and growth in the market. As my friend the member for Flinders said, Australia now ranks first among similar economies world wide in terms of the proportion of the population that owns shares. That growth has been under the Howard government not under the Australian Labor Party. It is important that the government continues to build on these great achievements and encourages increased share ownership.

The current Minister for Education, Science and Training, the member for Bradfield, the Hon. Brendan Nelson, when he was chairman of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations made this very apt comment:

quote.para: Employee share plans can promote productivity, motivate employees, foster long-term prosperity and, in general, nurture a better working environment.

speech.para: This is what the Howard government is all about. It is about promoting prosperity in this country and giving opportunities to all Australians to improve themselves and their family's lot in life. This government is about improving the economic situation for the Australian people and ensuring that Australians who aspire to be better than they currently are can become so. It will only happen under this government. I think the Australian people will remember that very clearly. I am pleased to support this motion and I encourage those opposite to support it as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I feel hesitant to rain on this parade of mutual admiration that seems to be going on across the chamber here, but it seems to me that the government and the speakers from the government side who have spoken on this have a very limited view of what might be the way that we could shape a better country for more Australians. If the result is to focus on the sale of Telstra and the great success story of that being that the member for Flinders is an owner of Telstra shares, then I am not sure that that is what we are all setting out to achieve. I know that he would also be the first to acknowledge that it is people like us in this chamber who have the resources to be able to participate in a whole lot of asset building activities, including the ownership of shares. Probably many in this chamber have had the benefit of some inheritance from their families, if not in terms of real assets then at least in terms of an understanding of how some of these systems work.

speech.para: I do not think that this is what the member for Flinders was seeking to make as his central point in this debate, but it seems to me that the government members have stuck very much to that line rather than looking at some of the more innovative approaches that we might be able to take in redistributing or at least spreading wealth more broadly across our country. I think that is why the member for Werriwa went through a number of the initiatives that have got great scope for us. I would hope that those members opposite who take an interest in the accumulation and redistribution and sharing of wealth and assets in this country might look closely at some of the proposals.

In particular, as our shadow minister for children and youth, I want to speak briefly about the nest egg accounts, or child trust funds, that are being implemented in Britain. I think it is worth exploring how such a proposal might apply in Australia and how it is a way not only for us to support children and their families but also, as the member for Werriwa has said, for us to start treating young people like the young adults that they are and providing them with the capacity to make some decisions for their future, enabling them to invest and build wealth for their future, enabling them to sustain their future lives and giving them the opportunity to decide to have children in the future. It seems to me that those sorts of proposals are likely to have a much greater intergener-ational effect than decisions which assist in the rollover of shares from one investment to another, which are only really benefiting those that are already in the system and already have sufficient wealth to be able to do this.

This is an opportunity for us to look in new ways at the way that we might support young people in this society and look at the fact that they will have to provide for themselves in the future. We know that the balance is changing in terms of the number of children and older people in our community and they need to be thinking about their futures even earlier on. I think this is one proposal that might lead us to do that. We have the benefit of being able to look at what is happening in Britain at the moment. They are trialling a system and introducing it, I believe, as we speak.

talk.start.para: —It's called the baby bonus!

—No, it is not called a baby bonus. It is not called giving more money to those people who earn more money. It is actually called giving more money to those people who have less, so they can build their wealth for the future and their inheritance for their children in the future. In fact, it is the very opposite of the baby bonus. The member for Flinders would do well to take some of these ideas, which he can clearly see the benefit of, into his party room and argue why the baby bonus could be better spent on some of these sorts of options. I know that, for anyone with any intellect—as the member for Flinders certainly is—there is no rhyme or reason for introducing a system that favours the wealthy.

(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for private members' business has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The honourable member for Gellibrand will have leave to continue speaking if and when the debate is resumed.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Services answers all criticisms of the Job Network by saying it is a work in progress. It is not. It is an established government program that, after five years, is showing fatigue—and, I must say, a considerable amount of fatigue, with a lot of intensive assistance clients going through it for the second, third and fourth times without getting satisfactory outcomes. The reason they are not getting satisfactory outcomes is that the program has serious structural and policy defects. These defects were exposed in the draft report of the independent inquiry into the Job Network conducted by the Productivity Commission.

speech.para: The Job Network is a creation of the Howard government and, after five years, the government is accountable for these failings. As a result of the draft report of the Productivity Commission, the government has been forced to make some modifications to the Job Network for the next round of contracts. These were announced in the budget. As is typical of the Howard government's approach to policy development, these changes were announced in advance of the completion of the Productivity Commission's final report, which was handed to the government on 3 June. But three weeks later we are still waiting for its release. The main defects exposed by the Productivity Commission relate to the incentives structure provided by the government to Job Network providers in their contracts. The principal defect in those incentives structures under the current contract is the high outcome payments for intensive assistance.

A Job Network provider receives a commencement fee of about $2,122 for each client referred to them. If they can place that job seeker in employment that lasts 13 weeks, the Job Network provider receives an interim outcome payment of $4,953. If the job lasts for 26 weeks, the Job Network provider receives a final outcome payment of $2,144. The government's theory was that Job Network providers would take financial risks to achieve outcome payments by spending significant amounts of money to make eligible job seekers job ready. With $9,219 per job seeker guaranteed or in prospect, superficially that might have seemed likely. But, not surprisingly, Job Network providers in a competitive environment focus on achieving as many of those $4,953 interim outcome payments as they can at the least cost. The consequence is what the Productivity Commission refers to as `parking'. As the commission said:

quote.para: There is evidence that a substantial proportion of job seekers are `parked'—that is, receive a minimal level of service. This is a problem, as active participation by the job seeker in job search or training appears to be positively correlated with service levels.

speech.para: Job Network providers quickly identify the job seekers who are most disadvantaged and give them the least service. This is the antithesis of what intensive assistance is supposed to do. Instead, the government's incentive structure encourages Job Network providers to focus upon what the Productivity Commission calls `creaming'—that is, they `only handle job seekers for whom a job can be found easily and cheaply'. The potential return on an intensive assistance client who is already job ready, as many are, is around $9,000. Job Network providers can achieve 77 per cent of that potential with the interim outcome for a 13-week placement. Hence, the rather commercial promotional schemes for employers such as Mission Employment's flat screen TVs, DVDs and golf clubs as rewards for keeping a job seeker in work up to the point of the interim outcome payment.

On the other hand, the incentives for achieving secondary outcomes, such as placing a disadvantaged job seeker in training, are much smaller. The commencement fee of $2,122 is the same but both the interim and final outcome payments are each only $536. The total return for assisting a disadvantaged job seeker who is unlikely to find work is only $3,195. This is the mismatch between needs and price signals. The less assistance the job seeker needs, the higher the reward for the Job Network provider. The more disadvantaged the job seeker and the more they need, the lower the reward. Obviously, some Job Network providers provide disadvantaged job seekers with more than a minimal level of service, but there is no doubt that the incentive structure provided in Job Network contracts does not encourage this. The disadvantaged get parked; the job ready provide the cream.

Publicly, the Minister for Employment Services prefers to ignore the Productivity Commission's findings. Instead he likes to make a financial comparison between the cost of the Job Network and the Working Nation program it replaced. According to the government's own submission to the independent review of Job Network, it is an explicit intention of government `to return labour market assistance expenditure to pre-Working Nation levels'. What does that mean? The government has certainly cut spending on labour market programs, averaging expenditure of $1.35 billion per year over its first four years compared to an average annual expenditure of $3.7 billion over the first two years of Working Nation. I do not think either the Howard government or the opposition should disagree on the fact that Labor gave a higher priority to active labour market programs.

The comparisons the Minister for Employment Services likes to make are between the average cost per job seeker under the two sets of programs because they have declined under the Job Network. The minister's own departmental submission to the independent review of Job Network provides a useful comparison between intensive assistance and Working Nation. According to these figures, the average cost of getting a job seeker off benefits on Working Nation was $35,100 compared with $22,010 on intensive assistance. The average cost per employment outcome was $12,075 on Working Nation and $6,200 on intensive assistance. The average cost per participant on Working Nation was $3,320 and $2,260 on intensive assistance. But while intensive assistance is cheaper than the Working Nation program it replaced, this is a set of comparisons that requires qualification. In particular, unlike intensive assistance, Working Nation guaranteed every eligible job seeker a place in either a training program or a work placement with a wage subsidy. A large part of the cost differential between Working Nation and intensive assistance was that Working Nation gave every long-term unemployed person real assistance to get a job; there was no `parking'.

The changes to the Job Network address the `parking' problem with the job seeker account. This is intended to create the impression that job seekers will be guaranteed a level of support. The problem is that the provider's job seeker account will only be credited with, firstly, $11 and then $953 to pay for assistance for each eligible job seeker. That is recognition that job seekers are not even getting a minimal level of assistance under the current contract. Nor is any job seeker guaranteed access to even that minimal level of assistance under the new arrangements. The provider can pool that money and spend more on one job seeker and none on another. So much for the proposed so-called service guarantee. The job seeker account simply contains some money the provider must spend on eligible types of assistance for some job seekers or return it to the government.

The definition of eligible expenditure is broad— for example, Mission Employment's promotion giving golf clubs and television sets to employers to place a job ready applicant could be paid for out of a provider's job seeker account. At the same time, a disadvantaged job seeker needing some specific training to make them job ready might get no support through the job seeker account. Obviously, but in contradiction of current government policy, incentives to employers ought to be paid out of outcome fees and the use of job seeker account money for expensive gifts to employers ought to be prohibited.

More generally, the incentive structure has not been changed sufficiently to guarantee disadvantaged job seekers the support they need. Under the new arrangements we will not see an end to the problems of `parking' and `creaming'. There needs to be a real rebalancing of the incentive structure in Job Network contracts. The level of risk for providers in spending on support for the most disadvantaged unemployed needs to be reduced so that they will be guaranteed the kind of help they need to make them job ready.

Obviously, if the risk is reduced, the rewards—currently taken as profit from creaming—must also be reduced. At the moment, the taxpayers' employment services dollar is being used inefficiently. Large profits are taken by some providers for placing people who need little assistance. Those scarce dollars are not being spent on the disadvantaged—those whom the program is supposed to have been designed to help. The providers who are not making supernormal profits because they are providing an appropriate level of assistance to disadvantaged job seekers would not be adversely affected by such a rebalancing of risk and reward. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today on a matter of great importance to my home state of South Australia—the state of South Australian politics and those involved in it. As you would be aware, on previous occasions I have expressed my concerns to the House with regard to the conduct of the Speaker of the House of Assembly in South Australia. However, in the months that have ensued, I have become aware of some much more disturbing information, and I now feel that I can no longer sit quietly and allow this information to be hidden from the South Australian public—or the Australian public, for that matter.

speech.para: As this saga that is South Australian politics unfolds, the water just gets murkier and murkier. We have all heard about the dealings that Mr Lewis is said to have had with convicted armed robber Mr Terry Stephens, and we have all heard about the alleged shady business deals, but up until now I do not think that any of us have been aware of just how far these dealings may have gone. To make my concerns clear, I would like to provide the House with some details as background to this saga and as they have been provided to me.

Late last year, Mr Terry Stephens—alleged business partner of Peter Lewis, Speaker of the South Australian House of Assembly—managed to purchase the Shenandoah mansion of disgraced former magistrate Mr Peter Liddy following his conviction on paedophilia charges. I say `managed' because how a convicted criminal can be allowed to purchase a mansion known to have guns as part of its contents is beyond me. Who authorised this sale? However, the fact remains that Mr Stephens purchased the mansion. I am also told and have received the paperwork that shows that Mr Stephens borrowed a sum of $200,000 from a lending company called Capital Access with an attached interest rate of 120 per cent per annum to assist with the purchase of the mansion—a loan which he then defaulted on without making the first payment. At this point the company Capital Access, instead of putting the property up for sale, as would usually happen, took the unusual step of taking control of the property and installing a person at that property involved with a well-known bikie gang, the Gypsy Jokers.

On the surface of it, this appears to be strange. However, if we delve deeper, it is even stranger than first thought. After hearing this, I immediately began to wonder who Capital Access were and what their interest in the Liddy mansion, Terry Stephens and, ultimately, Peter Lewis, by association, may be. Apparently, it is common knowledge amongst the Adelaide legal and corrective fraternity that Capital Access is a company that, amongst other legitimate dealings, launders money for the Gypsy Jokers bikie gang and is well known for this. But what appears to be less known is that Capital Access is also a company that has allegedly lent Mr Peter Lewis, Speaker of the House of Assembly in South Australia, large amounts of money. As I have said previously, the more the story unfolds, the murkier the waters get and the harder it is to believe that we are indeed talking about South Australian politics and not a Mario Puzo Mafia novel.

I am extremely bothered by the information that has come my way because all it does is pose more questions for which I do not have the answers and raises even more doubt as to the character of the person who is now the most powerful person in South Australian politics. What is the interest of the Gypsy Jokers in Peter Liddy and his assets? What is the interest of the Gypsy Jokers in Terry Stephens and Peter Lewis? Did Peter Lewis know about Terry Stephens's dealings with the Gypsy Jokers? What were Peter Lewis's own dealings with the Gypsy Jokers and the company Capital Access? What, if any, obligations does Mr Lewis have to this bikie gang or Capital Access, and how will this impact on his role as the most powerful man in South Australian state politics?

It is scary stuff and something which should not be kept from the public any longer. Usually, on the face of it, when allegations arise, one can make a benefit-of-the-doubt decision based on the character of the person against whom the allegations are made. Once again, I wish that it were that simple in this case. What concerns me is yet more information that I discovered while trying to verify what I had been told which only serves to raise more questions to be answered. It appears that Mr Lewis is not quite of the character that we are used to having in a Speaker.

The Advertiser, the local daily newspaper in South Australia, took great delight on many occasions to report some `interesting anecdotes' relating to Mr Lewis. For example, on 24 August 1996 the Advertiser ran a story on page 1 titled`Taxpayers foot bill for MP's honeymoon bus trip'. The story alleged that Peter Lewis took his wife of one day and their overseas wedding guests on a nine-day sightseeing tour to Sydney and claimed it as official travel, with the cost to taxpayers being more than $3,000. On 9 April 1997, they ran a story about Peter Lewis being ordered to repay over $3,000 in overseas phone calls and faxes made by him and his wife to South Korea for her to conduct business. The then Speaker of the House of Assembly placed an overseas bar on Mr Lewis's phone and ordered him to repay those costs. But it is then alleged that he began to use his phone/fax to make these calls, because there was not a bar on the phone/fax. This piece of information is of particular concern to me because, now that Mr Lewis is Speaker, who is going to police this sort of conduct and what is to stop it from happening again? Who is going to police the parliamentary policeman?

On 11 April 1998, the Advertiser ran another story claiming that Mr Lewis did not tell the state government that his wife owned the property which was approved for lease as his electorate office. Apparently he said that he did not want Mr Ingerson—the minister then in charge of those things—to know that the government would be paying $15,000 a year in rent to his wife, Ms Kerry Davidson, who had registered the property in her Korean name. On 20 March 1998, the paper ran another story, on page 6, about Mr Lewis launching Supreme Court action against the Murraylands Regional Tourist Association because he was voted off the committee at a meeting he did not even attend.

On the same day the paper reported that Mr Lewis was in a quarrel with the Department of Administrative Services because it denied him his own exclusive car and driver, despite the fact that he was not entitled to be issued with one. It is also alleged that he even tried to claim parliamentary privilege for his many speeding fines. That brings the whole parliament into disrepute—and add to that the allegations that Mr Lewis tried to import venison into South Korea without the proper permits and then kicked up a huge fuss because we would not help him to get this venison into South Korea illegally. The fact that Mr Lewis has just been given $21,000 of taxpayers' money by the Labor government in South Australia to fund his personal legal action against a former state governmenteven though the previous committee rejected the court action and even though Peter Lewis boasted that it was being funded by him alonegives us a slightly clearer insight into who Peter Lewis is and what he stands for.

However, the question remains: how far will he go? On the face of this information one could form an opinion that Mr Lewis might have poor judgment when it comes to determining what he can claim under his parliamentary entitlement and what he cannot. But does this mean that he would knowingly get involved with such serious criminals as it has been alleged that he has? I honestly do not know. There are just too many unanswered questions here. Mr Lewis is unarguably the most powerful man in South Australian politicshe knows it; the Premier, Mike Rann, knows it; and we know it.

I am extremely concerned about the amount of unanswered questions. I think that the only way we can resolve this issue once and for all is to demand a royal commission into the sale of the Liddy mansion to Terry Stephens; what involvement, if any, Peter Lewis and the Gypsy Jokers had; and what exactly happened with the sale as well as with the guns and other contents of the mansion. Thereby we can determine whether or not the most powerful man in state politics was involved. I do not think we can rest until South Australians know who is governing them. I certainly know that I will not. I grieve at the precedent that has been set by the Speaker of the House of Assembly in expunging his own comments from Hansard. I grieve that we now have a Speaker in South Australia who thinks he can take part in debate instead of appearing unbiased. Frankly, this Speaker in the South Australian parliament, Peter Lewis, is not only dangerous but also an embarrassment to everyone. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is nice to see you in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott. I am very pleased that the Minister for Ageing is in the House because what I intend to grieve about today is a situation which causes a great deal of uncertainty and concern for residents in my electorate of Bowman—that is, the fact that there are not sufficient beds in my electorate to go around. It is a situation that is in urgent need of government attention.

speech.para: I say that I am pleased that the Minister for Ageing is in the House because he is a person for whom I have a great deal of personal respect. I know that he probably does as much as he can do with the funds that he has got available. But I want to appeal to him—luckily, he is in the House—to perhaps come along to my electorate one day in the not too distant future and have a look for himself as to why there is such an acute shortage of beds—nursing home high-care beds—in my electorate. It is mainly because it is an area that a lot of people like to retire to. It is close to the water, it has beautiful breezes and it is a retirement area that is much sought after.

The Treasurer's Intergenerational Report confirmed what most Australians are already painfully aware of, which is that we live in an ageing community. That trend is not going to be reversed quickly given current migration levels and fertility rates. The government, of course, was swift to propose cost-cutting measures to address this position by way of the pharmaceutical benefits changes that I was pleased to see defeated in the Senate last week. However, very important questions about how we ensure that the senior members of our community are able to access the accommodation and the care they require as their needs change still remain unanswered.

In recognition that the challenges associated with an ageing community are particularly acute in Queensland, the Queensland Premier, Peter Beattie, last week announced the creation of a Ministry for the Ageing. This is an important initiative for which he ought to be congratulated. I call upon the federal government to likewise acknowledge that the ageing question is of heightened importance, particularly in my home state of Queensland. I am fortunate to live in and represent one of the most beautiful parts of our country: the bayside area of Brisbane—which includes Wynnum, Manly, Lota and those areas—and the Redland shire, which is on the outskirts of Brisbane. In Bowman not only do we have the advantage of a short 40-minute trip by car to the CBD; we also enjoy the many lifestyle benefits that living on Moreton Bay has to offer. As such, it is little wonder that our community is becoming increasingly sought after as a retirement destination.

Bowman virtually takes in all of Moreton Bay—in fact, I will be going to Moreton Island at the end of this week to visit my constituents for the first time in many years. It is a beautiful area. As a result we have people coming from down south and from everywhere all over Australia to this particular pristine part of Australia and they want to retire there. The number of senior citizens that are coming there is extraordinary. There are retirement villages just down the road from my place—Wellington Manor, Cleveland Manor and others. They are just mushrooming up absolutely everywhere, and I can understand why. For instance, one of the villages in my electorate, Finlandia, is one which houses people of Finnish origin in the main, although it is open to general members of the public. It is the only place that brings in Finnish people from all over Australia. Effectively, my electorate of Bowman is becoming a retirement area for Finns from around Australia.

The Labor Party introduced a formula which allocated a certain amount of beds per district, and this government has continued with it. It might now be time to look at that formula—look at the areas where retired people are living—and perhaps give some consideration to those areas that attract so many retired people. The difficulties my constituents are currently experiencing in finding appropriate care for their loved ones whose age prevents them from living independently, and the concerns felt by local aged care operators who find themselves unable to provide ongoing care to residents as their needs change, are only going to get worse unless the government acts now to address the aged care bed shortage in my area. Applications for the 2002 aged care approvals round will be called for next month. This will see a flurry of activity from aged care providers in my local area. Groups like Lake Sherrin Homes at Thornlands and Finlandia Village at Cleveland know that a lot rests on their success as they compete for a share of the 130 high and low care beds that will be allocated to Brisbane south—an area that stretches along the Brisbane River from Wacol in the west, through Parkinson and down to Redland Bay. This area, according to the recently released census figures, has more than 93,000 residents aged 65 and over. Listening to those figures, it does not take a mathematician to work out not only that competition is stiff but also that there are members of our community—seniors who have worked hard to build a strong Australia—who are not receiving the care that they require and deserve.

Securing additional beds is a pressing issue for many providers in my electorate of Bowman. However, I take this opportunity to highlight the difficulties faced by a group struggling to cater for older members of our community with particular needs. The Prins Willem Alexander Village located at Birkdale in my electorate, not far from where I live, was established in the 1980s to provide hostel accommodation and low care beds for the local community, with a particular focus on servicing the needs of the Dutch community of greater Brisbane. There is a substantial community of Dutch expatriates in Queensland and it is estimated that nearly 25 per cent of its members are aged 65 years and over.

Prins Willem is highly regarded as a provider of quality services within an environment which is sensitive to the cultural and social needs of the Dutch community. In particular, residents of the village appreciate the provision of culturally sensitive care services and contact with care workers in their native tongue. However, the village's management, residents and supporters are increasingly concerned by their inability over the last six or seven years to secure additional high care beds to enable them to cater to the changing needs of ageing residents and to have more places available as members of the community reach a stage of their lives when nursing care becomes a reality.

As the member for the area, I have for many years actively supported their attempts to secure additional beds through the normal channels of the aged care approval round applications, but the village has had little success. Mounting concern among residents and the general community about the situation of Prins Willem is evidenced by the hundreds of letters that I, and I think the minister and many other members throughout Australia as well, have received. These letters, which I know have been received by many people, ask the following questions: what are we to do with our deteriorating residents? Where are we supposed to send them? How can they be expected to make new friends when they are plucked out of an environment they know, understand and appreciate?

In his response to my representation about this important issue, the Minister for Ageing correctly asserts that Prins Willem Alexander Village has 38 Ageing in Place beds, allowing beds to be used to admit patients who require either high or low care or to upgrade a low care place should the care needs of a patient change. While the aims of the Ageing in Place policy are to be supported, to be effective the allocation of Ageing in Place beds must be fortified by other assistance. Prins Willem may have 38 Ageing in Place beds, but the village has only 42 beds in total. To convert any number of their places to high care without any additional allocation would be a logistical nightmare, as the village would struggle to cover the costs associated with additional staff needed to provide high care residents with round-the-clock care. For this option to be viable, the village requires additional beds to allow care to current residents to continue while freeing up resources to introduce the infrastructure and staff required to administer high care beds.

While, according to the minister, it is not possible to transfer beds into regions that are already oversupplied, management at Prins Willem are understandably perturbed that they, together with other established service providers in the area, are unable to secure bed allocations, while new nursing facilities are able to be established with beds allocated to the provider based on operations in a different demographic area. Should this practice be allowed to continue, it would cause great upheaval and distress for residents in established local homes, such as Prins Willem Alexander Village, who could be forced to relocate to obtain appropriate levels of care.

Relocating is a bleak prospect that confronts many seniors in my electorate, including the many veterans who reside in Redlands and the Bayside, as they get to a stage where they require assistance to get through the minutiae of the everyday. A very good friend of mine, Mr Bill O'Connor, together with a number of other people within the RSL community in Redlands, has set up a committee—it has been going for a couple of years—to try to establish a specific veterans' home in the Redlands area. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott— being, like me, a former minister for veterans' affairs—these veterans like to stay in the one place. They like to keep their friends. They like to be able to move from low care to high care. We are trying to establish an RSL war veterans home down there. Of course the problem we have is the same problem a lot of other areas are facing: there are not sufficient beds. Whilst people are prepared to put forward the money for an RSL war veterans home, there are just no beds. In conclusion, I ask the minister to come and have a look at it, see what the problem is and see whether there is some way that he can assist.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this grievance debate tonight to speak about immigration.
