Much has been said recently about the need to improve facilities within immigration reception and processing centres to ensure that the government's policy of humane detention is adhered to. This is a very important issue, and the subject of some ill-informed, though perhaps well-meaning, criticism, over the past few months and weeks. No-one is suggesting that this is not a very difficult and, indeed, very complex issue.

speech.para: Simplistic responses as espoused by some commentators have been tried in the past and have simply failed. When such comments are reported in the Australian and international media, they are immediately seized upon by people smugglers. Illegal immigrants' expectations are unnecessarily raised that when they arrive in Australia they will immediately be released into the community or will be in detention for very short periods, regardless of whether they have any genuine claims to remain. When refugees are advised that they have no right to remain in Australia, their unmet expectations give rise to a culture of protest and in some cases, as we have seen, to unlawful riotous activity. All people commenting publicly on these matters in Australia should at least inform themselves of the global nature of the issue, the complexities, the involvement of criminal gangs, and the sheer determination of many people to live in Australia.

Under the refugee convention we are required to admit people who arrive in our territory in an unauthorised fashion where there is a question about their needing protection. Australia does this. We are not, however, required to permit full access to the Australian community until we are satisfied who they are and until they have undertaken health, character and security checking. Immigration detention in Australia is consistent with the UNHCR's detention guidelines. It is designed to ensure that applicants are available while their claims are assessed, to facilitate identification, health, character and security assessments and to ensure that they remain available for removal from Australia should they prove not to be eligible for the grant of a visa. That is why we have the policy of mandatory detention.

Despite the ALP apparently ditching its bipartisan support, those people are in Australia unlawfully, and we have not previously had the opportunity to check their identity and assess their claims. Australia's mandatory detention policy is not punitive, nor is it implemented as a deterrent or disciplinary measure. Mandatory detention is the result of being in Australia unlawfully, not the seeking of asylum. Detention of unauthorised arrivals is clearly prescribed in legislation and is subject to full parliamentary scrutiny and accountability. Some members of parliament and well-meaning advocacy groups from time to time have felt it necessary to air to the media a range of unsubstantiated and untested allegations about conditions in the centres and the behaviour of detention staff. Let me now refer to comments by Senator McKiernan, an ALP senator, in the Senate adjournment debate on 21 June 2001. I have enormous respect for that senator, and he had this to say about a detainee seeking refugee status:

quote.para: Recently there was a demonstration around Australian capital cities where banners were flown that said, `Free the refugees'. I agree with that; I support that. I do not believe any refugee should be detained in this country. But just as I do not believe a refugee should be detained, I do not believe that anybody who arrives unlawfully on our shores and who claims refugee status is automatically a refugee. Many of them are refused, and I think that something like 1,000 people have had their claims for protection refused and are now awaiting removal from Australia.

In my capacity as Chair of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, I have had many opportunities to look at individual cases through the course of our inquiries. I want to draw reference to one particular applicant for refugee status who was the focus of an inquiry, among other things, of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and whose case was featured in a report of committee called A sanctuary under review: an examination of Australia's refugee and humanitarian determination processes, which was tabled at about this time last year. There is a full chapter, chapter 7, that deals with Mr SE's case, and there is a chronology of events dealing with Mr SE at appendix 6. We called him Mr SE because he was an applicant for protection and we were respecting his privacy.

He is not an applicant any longer, but it is interesting to read how Mr SE took in the Australian community, and not only the Australian community but the Australian judiciary—advocates on behalf of the individual—by lying through his teeth throughout the process as to who he was. We can talk about that because the Legal and Constitutional References Committee actually went into the detention centre, talked to the person in question, took evidence from him and accepted the lies we were told, with his advocate present. Mr Sadiq Elmi arrived in this country in 1997 and made an application for protection that was refused. His appeal to the RRT was refused. I think he made about five or six requests to the minister to exercise his discretion, which were all refused. He was about to be removed from Australia when he convinced the pilot of the aircraft taking him out of Melbourne that he should not be removed. He then made application to the High Court of Australia. His advocates went off to the United Nations. The United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights requested non-removal from Australia and the person was taken off an aircraft out of Perth. The minister allowed Mr Sadiq Elmi to make a second application for refugee status. When, under the natural justice provisions of application for protection in Australia, Mr Sadiq Elmi was shown that the department knew he was not who he said he was and that, therefore, he was not entitled to refugee status, he withdrew his application and made arrangements to go somewhere else.

I make this point to the committee: they have heard evidence from many detainees, and not everything they were told during the course of their visits to the detention centres was in fact true. If they want to know what truth is, perhaps they should look at the case of Mr Sadiq Elmi and see how individuals like that will seek to twist and take advantage of Australia's humanitarian program.

speech.para: Australia has a proud history of humanitarian aid and resettlement, every year welcoming thousands of refugees under the second most generous per capita refugee and humanitarian resettlement program in the world, behind Canada. Over the last 20 years Australia's refugee program has been relatively stable, at around 12,000 per annum. The size and composition of Australia's refugee and humanitarian program are influenced by a number of factors. I will not go into too much detail about those factors but will mention two: an estimate of the number of people likely to be found in need of protection in Australia in accordance with international obligations under the UN refugee convention; and Australia's capacity to assist given budgetary implications in which it is estimated that over four years it costs as much as $30 million for every 1,000 refugees seeking refugee and humanitarian entrance. Australia has an excellent record in contributing to the alleviation of refugee and humanitarian problems around the world, including its humanitarian program and domestic processes for onshore asylum seekers. Australia is taking a consistent position which provides protection for those in genuine need and ensures that all claims for protection are properly considered yet makes it clear that illegal immigration will not be tolerated. Let me read from a UNHCR web site article about Kenya. It states:

quote.para: A food crisis is looming at Kakuma refugee camp [northwestern Kenya] which hosts 68,000 people.
Reports said the camp, which hosts 68,000 people, had food to sustain the refugees for only two months. This has forced the World Food Programme to reduce its rations.

The looming crisis became evident on Sunday [9 June] when 2,000 refugees, whose names were not on the food rations register, fought. Eight people were arrested and taken to Kakuma police station but they were later released afterwards.
An official of the World Food Programme said the agency had reduced its food rations from 2,166 kilo calories to 1,997 kilo calories a day for each refugee.
She said the supplies would be reduced further next month unless donors intervened.

speech.para: The point that I am making there is that there are genuine refugees who are in need and who are being kept out by illegal immigrants. If our ability to seek out and resettle people is reduced by people smugglers bringing people to our shore, people like those in the Kakuma camp will miss out because they will never be able to hire a smuggler. Many will continue to face starvation because resources in Australia and in other countries will be diverted to deal with those who have the money and the opportunity to engage a people smuggler, whether or not they are refugees.

In closing, I say this: the successful settlement of humanitarian entrants relies upon their acceptance by the broader community. In this regard, volunteers play a valuable role in making new entrants feel welcome and helping them to establish contact with their neighbours, places of worship and sporting organisations, and linking them with the relevant ethnic associations. I say to those people who are speaking out publicly today: stick to your sporting expertise and let the issue of illegal immigrants be undertaken through the parliament by the government of the day and in the interests of Australia's security. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I cannot allow the comments of the member for Hume to go unchallenged. If he is asking for people not to comment on Australia's refugee and humanitarian programs, that is shocking. The Australian public have just as much right to an opinion as the member for Hume does, and I would say that a lot of the Australian public are better informed than he is about this issue. He is talking about a group of genuine refugees being displaced by illegal people coming here. He misses the fact that, under international law, people have a right to seek asylum in countries. He also misses the fact that the number of genuine refugees accepted by this government is quite small in comparison with the number of refugees going to countries in Europe, North America, Canada and so on. What he failed to point out when he talked about the genuine refugees being displaced was the number of people who have been accepted under the refugee category. The nominal number is 12,000 a year. In 2000-01 we were 1,600 short on that target. We have been short for several years on reaching that target; we are not even filling the 12,000 quota.

speech.para: On top of that, perhaps the member for Hume would like to ask himself how many of those people were Afghanis. At the time that we knew that Afghanistan was ruled by a government against which we were later prepared to go to war—to send Australian soldiers to fight and die in Afghanistan—how many Afghani refugees came through the official stream to Australia? The number was 81 in a year. Those thousands of people who are waiting in queues overseas that the member for Hume feels so sorry for will keep on waiting.

talk.start.para: —Where were you before the 2001 election? Why didn't you make those comments then?

—I did, actually. The member for Hume asks why I did not make these comments at the time of the election. If he would like to have a look, he will notice that those comments have been made by me on the public record in this place many times as well as in my election material, in public and in my newsletters.
—He displays his ignorance, and he is not even prepared to finish listening to my comments in response to him.

speech.para: What I did want to speak about tonight is something that concerns many Australians and has undermined public faith in democracy itself. I am referring to the case of Andrew Theophanous, a former member of this House, and his conviction on four of the six charges made against him. I do not want to go into the details of that case, because I believe there is a possibility of appeals before the court. Speaking in a very general sense, though, there were some very disturbing elements in the case. Perhaps the most disturbing for me were the reports that contain transcripts of conversations of Mr Theophanous discussing whether he might have a sexual relationship with a Chinese woman who was seeking help with her migration issue. I believe that this sort of case is akin to sexual assault. If someone is having sex that is obviously not consensual, the comparison has to be made with sexual assault. I am very seriously concerned about this particular aspect of the case but, as I said, I do not want to go into too many details of the case because I would not like to see any of my comments prejudice further proceedings.

One of the aspects of the case which has provoked a lot of public concern—and I think quite rightly so—is that, should the charges and conviction be upheld, when Mr Theophanous leaves jail he will be entitled to a lifetime gold travel pass. It is an oversight on the part of the parliament that these travel passes are not treated in the same way as superannuation entitlements where criminal activity has been proven. I think the Australian public would expect that, if someone is guilty enough not to be entitled to receive their superannuation, they are certainly guilty enough not to be entitled to the accompanying benefits of a lifetime gold pass. Although Mr Theophanous's wife has said that they would not make use of the gold pass unless and until Mr Theophanous is cleared of the charges, I am not reassured by that. If such a case should ever arise again, the same issue will arise. I think the minister has already made some noises that the regulations might be changed such that people who lose their superannuation entitlement will also lose their gold travel pass. I think that is very important; in fact, it rather surprises me that the regulations regarding gold travel card entitlements seem to be largely at the discretion of the minister. This is certainly a matter for the whole parliament. It is very important that other parliamentarians show their support to the minister if indeed he is considering changing these provisions.

I certainly do not think that we will find any objections amongst members of parliament who wish to be perceived by the public as upstanding and prepared to work hard and follow the rules. I think that in cases such as the one that I referred to earlier, there is a real issue with all parliamentarians being tarred with the same brush as the person who has been convicted of a particular outrage. I think it is very important, and it would be very good symbolism, for parliamentarians to say, `We accept that, if someone is convicted of serious charges such as this, they shouldn't receive any sorts of entitlements upon retirement or, in this case, upon leaving jail.'

I understand why this oversight may have occurred. I think that it is very hard to make laws and regulations assuming that people will behave so badly. We do have to have a certain level of trust in one another or the notion of democracy falls down. We do not expect people to behave corruptly or to solicit bribes or to solicit sex. We cannot work under the assumption that parliamentarians regularly do this sort of thing, or our faith in democracy is destroyed. But now that we have had the issue drawn to our attention, I think it is important for the public's faith in democracy to take it up and to change the rules to make sure that this sort of anomaly will never exist again.

I want to conclude by saying that, when parliamentarians have been accused and found guilty of travel rorts, I think that a very apt punishment for that sort of behaviour would be to withhold their eligibility to a gold pass, if in fact they are eligible for that on retirement. I am not being partisan at all. I am perfectly prepared to admit that Senator Mal Colston, who in May 1997 resigned as Deputy President and was later charged with 28 counts of misuse of travel entitlements, was once upon a time a Labor member, long before this misuse was discovered. He saw greener pastures and was attracted to them. The fact that that prosecution was dropped, in my view, is shameful. I think the last we heard from him was when he wrote to say that a meal allowance should be added to his travel pass entitlement. That is really not someone who should still be travelling on the taxpayers' purse. There are a number of other cases that I remember: Noel Crichton-Browne was fined $4,000 after admitting two charges of using entitlements to fund resort weekends with a female companion; Michael Cobb, in October '98, was convicted of six charges relating to travel expenses, fined $1,400 and given a two-year suspended sentence; Bob Woods was given an 18-month suspended sentence after pleading guilty to six charges relating to travel entitlements; the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government was found guilty because the DPP had advised police that there was, at that stage, insufficient evidence to establish the commission of a criminal offence; and I believe Winston Crane is still being investigated for a similar allegation. I think that where people have been convicted of a crime—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—I understand that the member for Parramatta will say that the member for Sydney was skating very closely to the sub judice law all the way through her speech, and at the end she infringed.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the member for Sydney suggested that the Member for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government had been found guilty.
—No, I didn't!
—You could look at the Hansard. Perhaps you were not intending to say that but I think that is what the Hansard will show. Perhaps it would be helpful if you clarified directly.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: if I did, in fact, read the quote wrongly, what I wanted to say was that the DPP had advised the police not to proceed further because:

quote.para: ... there is insufficient evidence to establish the commission of a criminal offence by any party.

speech.para: That is what I intended to say.

talk.start.para: —That is clear. Thank you, Member for Sydney.

—My grievance is on an issue which is of prime importance to my electorate. When people think of Australia's exports, they generally think about primary produce—in particular, coal, crude petroleum and iron ore. An industry that does not always come first to mind, but which increased its exports by an incredible 35 per cent last year, is passenger motor vehicle exports. Exports of passenger motor vehicles are now Australia's 10th-largest export, with a value of $3.1 billion. Australia's automotive exports last year totalled $4.9 billion. That is a long way from 1986, when our automotive exports totalled $463 million. Our major markets for motor vehicle exports are the Middle East, the United States, New Zealand and South-East Asia. In fact, in the last week, Holden has announced that it is expecting to export 18,000 rebadged Monaros to the United States. The value of that export is approximately $500 million.

speech.para: My electorate of Boothby contains many companies which are involved in the manufacture of passenger motor vehicles or components. Companies such as Mitsubishi, Monroe, Hendersons and Bridgestone are all important links in the automotive supply chain. The automotive industry nationwide employs almost 55,000 people, with 26,000 jobs directly employed in vehicle manufacturing. The industry has responded positively to tariff reductions from 50 per cent to the present level of 15 per cent. The value of production has grown to 17.4 billion, or over one per cent of Australia's GDP.

Local car production is approximately 350,000 units per year, of which 110,000 were exported last year. There have also been significant improvements in the quality and cost of Australian motor vehicle manufactures. A reform which was opposed by Labor, but which was supported by the government and which benefited the motor vehicle industry, was tax reform and moving to the new tax system. In the lead-up to the new tax system on 1 July 2000, we constantly heard that there was a danger of a buyers strike. In fact, one of the reasons I supported the new tax system was because it reduced the heavy burden of taxation on the car industry, and the car industry recognises that today.

In order to increase its competitiveness, the automotive industry adopted the `just-in-time' system to inventory management. The `just-in-time' inventory system enables motor vehicle manufacturers to hold small quantities of inventories, thereby boosting efficiencies. Unfortunately, it has made them vulnerable to supply shortages. An industrial dispute at a small component manufacturer will rapidly affect the whole industry. Motor vehicle production will be quickly affected and they and other component manufacturers will be brought to a halt. The Australian Manufacturing Workers Union has used this system to shut down the industry. Since August 2001, there have been four separate industrial disputes that have either shut down the industry or threatened to shut it down. In fact, the AMWU's 2001 campaign was to target companies with a large or militant work force that had a strategic vulnerability in the supply chain. Put simply, the AMWU is engaged in industrial warfare. Unions such as the AMWU and the Metal Trades Federation of Australia need to understand that there is no place for class warfare; there is no place for adversarial industrial relations in the workplace. Employers and employees should work together for their mutual benefit. This needs to occur at a workplace level as all workplaces are different.

Disputes at Tristar in August last year and Walker Australia in April this year have shut down the industry. The two disputes resulted in hundreds of millions of dollars of lost production. At these disputes, the union and workers ignored decisions and orders of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Federal Court by taking unprotected unlawful action. I believe that the only reason the component manufacturers did not sue the union and the organisers was that it was a condition of the agreement to go back to work.

More recently, the BHP Billiton strike saw helicopters being used to transport steel over an illegal picket line. The encouraging thing about that dispute was that BHP won injunctions against the illegal picket line and won the right to sue individual unionists for damages. But these actions not only threaten exports and investment but also threaten workers' jobs. There is already talk of Holden and Ford looking overseas for components. What does the AMWU do in the face of its members losing their jobs? The secretary of the AMWU already boasts of more industrial disputes which will threaten even more jobs. Over the next 12 months, there are something like 500 EBAs to be renegotiated in the automotive industry. The AMWU has signalled that it will use these renegotiations to apply the same sort of industrial pressure it has applied on Tristar and Walker Australia. Geoff Polites from Holden has described the prospect of this as `absolutely frightening'.

But when the AMWU are threatening the future of the successful motor vehicle industry, what do we hear from the Australian Labor Party? The Australian Labor Party are in a difficult position here because they are unable to defend the indefensible. They are unable to tell the union—as they are a significant donor to the ALP—to pull their head in. The ability of Australian manufacturers to attract investment from their parent companies is dependent on a number of factors, one of which is the industrial relations climate. The Vice President of the Ford Motor Co. has already labelled Australia `strike country'. Senior executives at GMH have never seen an industrial climate like this—and this was before the Tristar dispute in August last year. Once again, Australia's international reputation is becoming known for militant unions.
I want to highlight something from Mitsubishi's submission to the Productivity Commission inquiry regarding these strikes. The submission stated:

quote.para: The industry cannot limp from one dispute to another without severely eroding confidence levels in domestic and, particularly, export customers and our shareholders, as we compete for limited available investment capital.

speech.para: The Tristar dispute occurred as the Prime Minister was in Japan to lobby on behalf of Australian workers at Mitsubishi. The Walker dispute occurred as the investment decision for the new Magna Verada was about to be made. The actions of the AMWU are just unreal; those people are not living in a real world. They are doing enormous damage to Australia's reputation as an efficient, reliable and innovative manufacturer. The actions of the ultramilitant union are putting at risk the jobs of the workers they purport to represent. It is not possible to continue to act as if the car industry is a sheltered workshop with no exports to deliver and no competition from imports. The automotive industry is highly competitive worldwide with significant overcapacity and much competition for foreign investment. It is critical that the car industry works towards a cooperative model of workplace relations which will be in the interests of both the workers and the enterprise.

Today in question time we saw outrage at the linking of assistance to the industry with the workplace relations model that the Labor Party adopt. That is nothing more than a smokescreen. What it shows is that the Labor Party are unable to defend the actions of these unions, but they are unable to tell the union to pull their head in. The best they can hope for is that no-one will notice. Nothing can hide the damage that the AMWU is doing. Car makers and others who suffer lost production due to the downstream effect of illegal industrial action should use the full force of the law to recover their damages. This is an industry which is crying out for something akin to the NFF fighting fund. The industrial actions of Tristar, Walker Australia and BHP are more like the big confrontations which characterised our industrial relations climate in the 1970s. What we are seeing is an industry which is successful, a work force which has increased its productivity, which is threatened by a dinosaur-like union that is like a relic from an industrial museum, and an opposition which has three million reasons to say nothing.

talk.start.para: —While the member for Boothby should realise that the AMWU—I think he referred to them on 20 occasions—did not have the effect of precipitating the destruction of Ansett, nonetheless Ansett collapsed. On a number of occasions in this House I raised the plight of Ansett and made some remarks about my views on why this huge company—this iconic Australian aviation carrier—collapsed. To be quite honest, I would have looked to the failings of this government, although I concede the factors involved in this company's demise were complex. It would be wrong for me to conclude that the government alone caused the collapse, but I think it is fair to say that there needs to be a review of the open skies policy, given the absurd price war that went on leading up to the demise of Ansett and the restrictions upon other carriers purchasing shares in Ansett, which all seem somewhat stupid now.

speech.para: Whatever the reasons for the fall of Ansett, and with it the decline of companies dependent upon its survival, the real question is: what role can the government play in providing assistance in the light of its demise? What assistance can the government provide to the creditors and the former employees—and indeed some current employees, which I will refer to later? What help will the government provide to those regions that have thousands of unemployed flight attendants, customer service officers, engineers, caterers, pilots, cleaners, security staff, freight handling crew and others who have worked in the aviation industry? Spare a thought for the 700 Ansett employees who are awaiting their fate at a maintenance depot down in Tullamarine. They have been working minimally throughout this whole period; they have not received their entitlements, contrary to some news reports. Indeed, they are awaiting their fate. I have been informed by the local state member for Tullamarine, Ms Liz Beattie, and a number of employee representatives that, of the 700 employees, up to 400 may indeed be made redundant by the end of next month, but it could be that the whole of the 700 employees may lose their work. It is important to also note that, unfortunately, Qantas have not really provided to those Ansett employees any of the work that they have outsourced in recent months. Instead, they have chosen to have Air New Zealand and Singapore Airlines provide some of those functions. I think this will expedite the likely loss of employment for those 700 employees. So spare a thought for those employees.

In March this year, a delegation from the region covering my electorate and the electorate of the member for Calwell met with officers of the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and met directly with the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. We also discussed concerns about problems in the region as a result of the collapse of Ansett with the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for transport and regional services. This delegation represented the three municipalities of Macedon Ranges, Hume City Council and Melton City Council. There were also representatives of the employees affected and of those who were no longer employed, and the president of the Sunbury Village Traders Association was also in attendance.

Our message was simple: we estimate that about 4,000 people within the region have suddenly found themselves jobless. Of course, this is worst of all for those 4,000 workers and their families as they are directly, immediately and comprehensively hit by this demise. I will just refer to a number of examples. Not far from where I live, and certainly in and around the area of Sunbury including Riddells Creek, Lancefield, Romsey and Gisborne, there have been many families who have lost up to four jobs in the one family—in other words, it is not a case where a family might have lost one job. In one case in Sunbury, both parents and two of their children lost work as a result of the collapse. So the collapse has been devastating for many of these families, and the delegation that came to Canberra wanted to make a point about that.

But another telling point is that the fall of Ansett will continue to have a very broad adverse impact upon the region, economically and socially. Ansett in our region was akin to Ford in Geelong; the collapse of BHP in Newcastle is akin to the collapse of Ansett where I live and for those who I represent. Accordingly, in March this year, after the delegation visited Canberra, the member for Calwell and I wrote to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, requesting assistance for the region. Firstly, we requested the establishment of a subcommittee of three area consultative committees that would properly represent the area affected. Secondly, we sought support for Regional Assistance Program funding to support this subcommittee and provide the necessary work to establish specific proposals to create economic and employment opportunities in the region. Thirdly, we sought immediate recognition as a region in need of structural adjustment through the Sustainable Regions program.

On behalf of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government responded by indicating that, although he shared our concerns, budgetary constraints would deny the possibility of securing resources through the Regional Assistance Program to fund our requested subcommittee. Further, the delegation's request for recognition as a sustainable region was also out of the question, although he shared our concerns. Although we have been advised to engage with the area consultative committees—which I am happy to do, as is the delegation—the delegation feels very angry and let down by the lack of support to date. In fact, there is a feeling of despair among those delegates that attended Canberra so optimistically in March.

Accordingly, I asked the government to reconsider its position and provide some assistance to a region that has been hurt by this corporate disaster. The headlines in the newspapers may go away but the impact upon the electorates of Burke, Calwell, Maribyrnong and some others in Victoria—and no doubt in other electorates in other states—continue, as do the adverse consequential effects upon the local economies and the communities of the region. Those affected will not forget who was there to help and who was not there to help. I strongly hold the view that with such proper support, as a government should show, the region would respond favourably.

In my electorate there is a great potential for employment growth in a number of industries, not least of which are tourism and hospitality. At only 45 minutes from the CBD of Melbourne, the towns of Sunbury and Macedon, and others I have mentioned, would provide great potential for economic growth and employment prospects. Amidst a growing wine industry and the unique and beautiful landmarks such as Hanging Rock and Mount Macedon, this region is full of potential. The dual benefits of appealing attractions and proximity to Melbourne provide the essential ingredients for growth in tourism and other associated industries. I do not believe that we have reached our full potential, but with some assistance from the federal and state governments we will indeed get there. Accordingly, I can assure the government that the delegation and the community it represents will not give up in pursuit of the region. We expect a government fully engaged with the electorate and willing to understand our plight and work with us to provide some relief.

I should indicate furthermore, as an important aside, that there are indeed some Kendell employees awaiting some decisions to ensure that they receive redundancy. I ask the government to attend to this matter and indeed to those issues I have raised in order to ensure that the Ansett employees, their families and the community at large within the region are properly looked after.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The state Labor government for Queensland has once again completely and totally ignored the Sunshine Coast with the 2002-03 state budget which was handed down recently. Vital funding has not been provided and it is quite understandable that the people of the Sunshine Coast feel they have been ignored and shunned by the state Labor government, despite the fact that at the last state election a number of state Labor Party members were elected in the area. There is no major funding for the upgrade of the Sunshine Motorway, for the Bruce Highway to Brisbane, for better access into Maroochydore or for Caloundra Road. On a number of counts, the state Labor government has simply failed to provide funding.

speech.para: Indeed, the decision by the state government to put the upgrade of Caloundra Road further down in its list of priorities is outrageous, particularly as this much needed road improvement will not happen because at the last state election the people of the City of Caloundra chose to return the state Liberal member Joan Sheldon to represent them at George Street. It is absolutely outrageous that the state Labor government is prepared to play petty politics to such an extent.

But it does not stop at Caloundra. If you go to Buderim you will find that Buderim residents will have to wait longer for a police station because the state Labor member for Kawana, Mr Chris Cummins, has simply failed the people of the Kawana electorate—Buderim, in particular—in this particular respect. Perhaps well-known Sunshine Coast business consultant Ted Fitzgerald is correct in commenting that ongoing state Labor government resentment over the Sunshine Motorway tolls being lifted was being reflected in poor road funding.

The member for Kawana, Chris Cummins, claimed as a personal win the $11 million contribution by the state government to continue the $17 million Kawana arterial linking the Nicklin Way and the Sunshine Motorway. In fact, Mr Cummins had the gall to go to the Sunshine Coast media and claim that he felt like the cat who had swallowed the canary. He should have been honest and said that the state government had merely put up the money that it was already contractually bound to provide to help fund the road, along with the developer, Lensworth.

By comparison with the failure by the state Labor government to provide funding to the Sunshine Coast, it is interesting to note that the Gold Coast received some $120 million in road funding. The state government has also ignored the Sunshine Coast's proposed arts and convention centre and has instead given the Gold Coast a bucket $100 million for its convention and exhibition centre. You could understand that if the Sunshine Coast was a rust belt. Far from it. The Sunshine Coast has been growing at a rate of more than 15 per cent in the past five years, almost double the Queensland rate of growth. The Sunshine Coast is expected to overtake Wollongong as Australia's ninth largest city within three years, and analysts predict our population will grow at a rate of between 2.5 per cent and 3.2 per cent for the next 15 years, to see the Sunshine Coast population grow to approximately 380,000 people. With an average 134 new residents migrating to the Sunshine Coast each week, it is time the Labor state government gave the Sunshine Coast the infrastructure it deserves.

Perhaps the Sunshine Coast is suffering due to the fact that we do not have one common municipal voice. We have the City of Caloundra, the Shire of Maroochy and the Shire of Noosa. The Gold Coast for many years have had the Gold Coast City Council and this has been able to give the Gold Coast a corporate identity. They are able to badge themselves as a region, whereas the Sunshine Coast does not have this particular advantage. I will be the first to admit that the Sunshine Coast councils are endeavouring to work together through an organisation called SunROC—the Sunshine Coast Regional Organisation of Councils—but perhaps it is time to question the effectiveness of this and whether this is the appropriate way to operate given the continual pain inflicted on our roads and general infrastructure systems and our inability as a community to receive appropriate recognition from the state Labor government.

While the state Labor government obviously sees its political fortune in part tied to the Gold Coast seats it holds, is the fact that the state Labor government has so completely ignored the Sunshine Coast an indication that Premier Beattie has given up on the dud members we have on the Sunshine Coast—the state member for Kawana; the state member for Noosa, Cate Molloy; and the state member for Glasshouse, Carolyn Male? Perhaps he sees that they do not have any chance of holding their seats at the next election. Maybe they are going to be oncers. Maybe the Premier has seen through these ineffective members that the people of the Sunshine Coast are starting to regret that they ever returned to represent them in the state parliament in Brisbane.

It does not stop there. The refusal by the Premier and the Queensland government to accept the gift of the HMAS Brisbane from the federal government to be sunk as a dive wreck off Kawana-Mooloolabah is a further indication that the state Labor members are either unable or unwilling to advocate strongly our community's needs. Maybe this is yet another indication that the Premier has given up on Chris Cummins. Maybe their research is showing that Chris Cummins is on a hiding to nothing at the next poll.

Peter Beattie is not a fool. He does know, however, that Chris Cummins is an ineffectual local member and, given his lack of performance, his chances of holding that seat at the next election are clearly minimal. Maybe Premier Beattie is research driven. Maybe he is looking at Chris Cummins and the other state Labor members and saying, `Look, they can never hold those seats, so why waste money on their electorates?' It is all very well for Mr Beattie to play politics. It is all very well for him to make an assessment that the representatives of Labor at state level on the Sunshine Coast are duds, but it is not right that the people of the Sunshine Coast should be penalised. Cummins has had his chance to show that he is an effective local representative by supporting the project of sinking the HMAS Brisbane as a dive wreck, but he bowed to Beattie's pressure and he is in the process of depriving his constituents of a tourism and jobs goldmine.

It is also worth mentioning today the way in which the state Labor government has treated the hardworking people of the state of Queensland. For the fifth consecutive year, the Beattie government, in time-honoured ALP tradition, has delivered a net deficit budget, and this year it will spend almost half a billion dollars it does not have. This will bring the total deficit of the Beattie government to $3.16 billion. It also seems that the Caloundra and Nambour general hospitals will be hard hit through the scalpel that Peter Beattie and his thoroughly incompetent Minister for Health, Wendy Edmond, have taken to the health budget. This year it will actually drop by $127 million. With more bad news, I wonder whether Wendy Edmond will continue to disappear. Will she be there to answer the questions? It simply seems that she has run away and that she is unable to confront not only the people of the Sunshine Coast, whose health needs have been ignored by the state Labor government, but also the people of Queensland more generally.

The Beattie budget cut road spending by $12 million, and obviously the people of the Sunshine Coast share in this pain. Any sensible person would think that, in a rapidly growing economy such as Queensland's, the government would recognise the need to properly fund road construction and repairs. While Premiers Bracks and Carr are, to their credit, delivering reasonable unemployment rates, Queensland under Beattie retains its crown as the unemployment capital of Australia, with this Beattie budget predicting that Queensland's average unemployment rate will be 7.5 per cent—1.5 per cent higher than the projected national average of six per cent.

talk.start.para: —They put a few Liberals on the scrap heap at the last election.

—The member for Banks knows that Premier Beattie is a dud. I want to draw to the attention of the people of the Sunshine Coast and to the attention of honourable members the appalling job that the three state Labor members are doing on the Sunshine Coast. They have been unable, unwilling or unprepared to stand up on behalf of their constituents, with the result that, unlike the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast is being short-changed by way of government infrastructure and road funding. It just seems that, even though we have a number of state Labor members sitting in the parliament in George Street, they are simply unable to get across the message of the Sunshine Coast, with the result that the people of the Sunshine Coast must be greatly regretting the fact that they elected these state members to represent them in state parliament. These guys are duds. They should be thrown out.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Genuine Bargaining) Bill 2002, I note that we will be moving a second reading amendment and also amendments in detail in the committee stage of the bill. In his second reading speech on presenting the bill, the minister acknowledged the significance of enterprise negotiation. That phenomenon has been vitally important—and, in fairness to the minister, I think he recognises that—in terms of Australia's current economic position. The evolution of enterprise negotiations arose firstly very much under the encouragement of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. As part of the accord process for trade unions to secure wage rises on behalf of their members, they had to convince the commission that they had provided enough productivity offsets by way of work practice changes, award restructuring or other productivity improvements during the various processes of the accord and national wage case decisions which reflected those outcomes.

speech.para: I can give first-hand account that on numerous occasions I appeared in those proceedings and the parties were literally sent away because the commission was not satisfied that the productivity offsets justified the wage increase. In other words, that process itself instilled in the parties the recognition that productivity improvements and the development of best practice production and management techniques were essential not only from the point of view of simply self-interest in obtaining higher wages but also from the point of view of developing Australian industry. Indeed, many trade unions and employers took work force representatives overseas with them to see what was happening in other countries and to show managers and work forces the grade they had to play in to compete in what was becoming, and what is certainly now very much here, a global marketplace.

That period of time saw a significant education, if you like, of both Australian management and the Australian work force as to the standard and the pace of the game that we had to play, in terms of both quality and flexibility. By way of analogy, it is like watching a modern game of rugby league compared to a game 15 years ago. It is much faster, much more flexible and in many ways far more skilled. That is the level of the game. What is frequently overlooked by this government are those tremendous improvements in productivity techniques, flexibility and generally the development of best practice models which, if not implemented with the consent of the trade union movement, in many instances were implemented as a result of the initiatives of the trade union movement in going along to workplaces and saying, `In order to obtain these second-tier increases, we've got to improve productivity. This is what is being done in other enterprises. How about sitting down with our members to work through whether this is appropriate for your enterprise?'

There is no doubt that that whole process, the evolution of that process, brought a great number of businesses from a system where they were producing for a domestic, fragmented market to a sophisticated model where they are producing for the rest of the world. We have heard today in debates, for instance, about the car industry. Fifteen years ago it was an industry under real stress, with tariff walls essential to protect us from going under in the face of international competition. We are now very much competing on that first-grade field, on the international field, and we are doing very well, if not winning. We are exporting about $7 billion a year in the automotive industry—the automotive industry being topical, of course, because of recent debates and the current industrial relations events occurring with so many enterprise agreements coming up for renewal on the one hand and, on the other hand, the Productivity Commission looking at the future assistance which the industry should receive, and I hope will receive, from the government.

The Labor Party very much supported the development of enterprise negotiations. I think it is fair to say we were stewards of that change till we got to 1993, when the parties themselves were able to negotiate enterprise agreements without arbitrated outcomes through the commission. That was the final step in the equation. Quite frankly, I think it is unfair of this government not to acknowledge the tremendous contribution that Australian workers have made to the development of the productivity of this nation. When I say Australian workers, I mean Australian workers and their elected representatives. It is regrettable and offensive to see that the government are constantly playing the political card of bashing the trade unions. Why do they do it? Because historically and in actuality trade unions are affiliated with the Labor Party. So attacking the trade union movement generally is seen as attacking the Labor Party. We are big enough and tough enough to cop attacks on our own. The member for Banks beside me is well-equipped indeed to counterthrust against any attack on him, and I think the frontbench are also quite prepared to accept and return political attack, but what is inexcusable is the denigration—for the purpose of what is literally a propaganda campaign—of trade unions, which are of course made up of Australian workers and their elected representatives.

Having said that, as I have said publicly on a number of occasions there is a small minority of trade unionists who I believe have not always acted in the interests of their members or in the national interest. But you do not approach your response to an industrial relations framework on the basis of the activities of a minuscule minority of people. That is my criticism of the government's approach. They are focusing on the activities of that minuscule minority for the purpose of blowing up disputation rather than developing systems that harness the tremendously constructive contribution that Australian workers, and Australian workers through their elected representatives, have made to this whole concept of enterprise negotiations.

I give that introduction to put into context the position which the Australian Labor Party take in response to the bill, which is titled the `genuine bargaining' bill. The bill essentially recycles, if you like, two earlier proposals introduced in the House and the Senate in 1999 and 2000. It must be acknowledged that this bill is a more moderate version of those earlier proposals, but nonetheless we believe it is misguided and, on that basis, we will be opposing it. In particular, we think it is misguided because it focuses on blocking activity rather than facilitating genuine bargaining through empowering the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make orders and give directions to parties to facilitate enterprise bargaining in good faith. As I say, we strongly support enterprise bargaining but we take a much broader approach rather than this one, which we believe is a ham-fisted response.

In particular, there is a whole range of actions that are required before protected industrial action can occur. There have to be resolutions of the relevant officials of the union, appropriate notice provisions and attempts to negotiate. The trouble is that when the system breaks down—and sometimes it can, it must be conceded—those procedures are seen more as rituals rather than activities of substance. We want to empower the commission to enable them to direct parties to negotiate in good faith so that they insist on each of these being activities of substance and not simply as part of a ritual. We do not want negotiations getting to the stage of the laws of the jungle where both sides kick into each other—with the unions taking industrial action, on the one hand, or employers embarking on lockouts in other regrettable instances, on the other hand. We say that the role of the umpire is a fundamental role and one which we will continue to press for. Indeed, we believe that, when the expertise of the commission is used by giving it a role as a facilitator of good faith bargaining, you are more likely to get agreements more quickly and more far-reaching agreements.

The government keep on saying they want to take third parties out of the enterprise relationship—taking third parties out of the relationship between employees and employers is their philosophy. To do so, however, they fail to appreciate the tremendously constructive role that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has played and can still continue to play even in these more flexible times of enterprise negotiations. There are two excellent recent examples. One involved BHP Western Port where there had been 23 days of stoppage before the commission became involved, and the matter was resolved within 24 hours of that occurring. The minister referred to the fact that common-law proceedings had been commenced. I think it is fair to say that the gateway, at least, for those common-law-proceedings was a good five days before that. That is not consistent with the actual events that occurred. Clearly, the commission played a very constructive role in the resolution of that dispute.

Another example is the resolution—or, at least, a means to the resolution—of a potentially crippling dispute in the airline industry involving air traffic controllers. Again, the good offices of the commission were able to prevail upon the parties to agree to a timetable of negotiations and a method for resolving those by way of arbitration at the end of it if no outcome was achieved. Because of the absence of powers of the commission to direct parties to negotiate in good faith, they were only able to achieve that by prevailing upon the good faith of the parties. Again, that was after there had already been actual industrial disputation, which caused quite significant disruption, I recall, for one day about a month ago to the airline industry. So the opposition will be moving amendments in consideration in detail with a view to restoring the powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to direct parties to negotiate in good faith.

But talking about the actual provisions of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Genuine Bargaining) Bill 2002, for instance, proposed section 170MW(2A), as the explanatory memorandum states, purports to provide `guidance' to the commission as to how they should approach enterprise negotiations when there is a commonality of claims across an industry. In fact, they refer to a significant decision of Justice Munro in the metals case of 2000. That case involved a situation where generally across the metal industry a number of enterprise agreements were terminating at the same time—a situation which we are now coming up to in 2002.

But, if you read that decision, guidance is not what is needed. Justice Munro was clearly able to set out what he regarded as factors indicating whether a party was genuinely negotiating. As we keep repeating, what is needed is the empowerment of the commission to enable the commission to be a facilitator to direct parties to negotiate in good faith. In fact, in that metals case Justice Munro used current section 170MW(1) to terminate a bargaining period of 33 employees because he was not satisfied that they were actually bargaining in good faith in respect of that enterprise. It is worth referring to the key finding of Justice Munro where he said:

quote.para: Does it follow that, if in truth the respondent negotiator is trying to secure agreement with all, or an entire class of negotiating parties in an industry—all or none—the respondent negotiating party is not genuinely trying to reach agreement with any individual negotiating party in the industry or class? In my view, it does. But in a particular case, a finding to that effect is dependent upon matters of fact and degree.

speech.para: In other words, there is no black and white prescription, as this legislation is attempting to impose. In explaining what he meant by `fact and degree', he said:

quote.para: Such questions of fact and degree obviously need to be answered by reference to evidence and details of particular facts. The more the negotiation conduct can be categorised as evidencing a refusal to allow agreement other than on an all or none basis, the greater the likelihood that it should be found to fail the genuinely try to reach agreement with the other negotiator test. However, there are variations and permutation of demands, conduct, and character of negotiating parties that must be assessed.

speech.para: So he approached it in a pragmatic way, looking at what was actually occurring—not on the basis of any ideological assumptions but on the basis of a genuine balance. Indeed, the government itself has now withdrawn reference in the legislation to pattern bargaining, but it is still used in the debate. That is, again, a flawed assumption. There will be many industries where a degree of commonality is essential from the point of view of practicality for all involved. Good examples would be in the retail grocery industry, in the retail hardware industry and, indeed, in respect of nursing homes. A commonality of enterprise negotiations will be necessary and, if you take the nursing home industry, probably desirable so that the standard of care provided to senior citizens in nursing homes is not dependent upon nursing homes trying to undercut or achieve productivity outcomes by reducing the terms and conditions of their professional staff. The fact that there is a commonality of bargaining does not mean that there is an absence of bargaining in good faith. That is the flaw, we believe, of the government's legislation. Indeed, Justice Munro, in the case to which I have referred, commented on that. As he said:

quote.para: A common set of demands for conditions of employment, or for timing of negotiating rounds and outcomes is not sufficient in itself to establish that a negotiating party is not genuinely trying to reach agreement with the counterpart party. I do not use the expression pattern to describe such demands. The notion of pattern demands or pattern bargaining lacks precision. It also has a partisan pejorative content.

speech.para: So he was alive to this concept, this expression, used by the government in trying to condemn that process. He noted that the process of attempting to obtain commonality of outcomes was quite frequently used from the employer's perspective as much as from the trade union perspective and you could not adopt this blanket assumption that this legislation presumes. Indeed, if you look at how the federal government itself approaches negotiations you will see there is very much a pattern to what the government does in this regard. As the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee found in its October 2000 report:

quote.para: Rhetoric about the decentralised environment of the Workplace Relations Act in which agency heads have flexibility to negotiate terms and conditions to suit their workplace has been misleading. The reality is that, while agencies have greatly increased flexibility, the Government is the ultimate employer and has in place policy parameters and guidelines to protect its policy interests.

speech.para: So it is quite hypocritical of the government to condemn this concept of a commonality of processes in circumstances where it is still doing that. Indeed, by way of policy parameters and guidelines, which one would think are essential for the orderly administration of the Public Service, it is engaging in that very process. An example is an edict from the minister's department on 7 June 2002 which revised the government's policy in respect of retrospective increases in remuneration for public servants. The policy now dictates that, other than in exceptional circumstances, pay increases are to apply prospectively. That is an edict that applies to negotiations which will take place, but that is a commonality. We can understand why the government may well give that edict, but, again, you cannot say that because that edict has been given the government must necessarily be not bargaining in good faith. You need much more precision to look at the facts, as Justice Munro said in his decision. The fact that this government has taken such a ham-fisted approach, we believe, prevents that occurring.

Another example is the way in which the government approaches negotiations for Australian workplace agreements within the department. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Legislation Committee recently revealed that when Senator Sherry asked the departmental representative, Dr Boxall:

quote.para: Has the department begun negotiations with individual employees or will it be commencing negotiations with individual employees about the terms of their AWA?

Dr Boxall—We have already processed some AWAs. So that you have a complete picture, all the AWAs in the department, which were in place before I arrived, expire on 30 June so the department faces quite a large task, because not only do the certified agreements expire on 30 June, so do all the AWAs currently in place.
Senator Sherry—It sounds like pattern bargaining to me. They all come out at the one time.
Dr Boxall—It is a statement of fact.

speech.para: It is, quite clearly, a statement of fact that there will be a commonality of policies in place. There will be a commonality of expiration dates. That in itself does not mean there is an absence of good faith bargaining. You need to be much more precise in determining that. As I have indicated, Justice Munro gave guidance and indicated that the commission is quite capable of determining that. The commission needs the ability to direct parties to negotiate in good faith. In other words, it needs to be empowered.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —In the short time that I have left I should focus some little time on the opposition's counterproposal, if you like, to what the government is talking about. Before doing so I should note that one of the proposals of the government is to provide for cooling-off periods as set out in section 170MWB. Indeed, I note that the Australian Industry Group has recently called for cooling-off periods and for the commission, in imposing a cooling-off period, to have regard to how third parties would be affected by industrial action. We see the reasoning in trying to limit the damaging effects of industrial disputation. Indeed, to the point where we are concerned that those proposals presuppose the occurrence of industrial action, what we would like to see instituted is a system where the commission literally is empowered to get amongst the processes to prevent that industrial disputation arising in the first place.

speech.para: Our concern is also that simply directing a cooling-off period without any requirement being imposed on the parties during that cooling-off period as to how they should conduct themselves and, indeed, not act to the prejudice of either of the respective parties that are limited by that very order necessarily requires the commission to have a role in how those negotiations will take place. For that reason we are proposing, as an amendment to this bill, re-empowering the commission to direct parties to negotiate in good faith—to actually get into the picture before disputation occurs. Those factors from a number of jurisdictions that are commonly adopted are: a requirement that parties agree to meet face to face; that they attend meetings that have been organised; that they comply with negotiating procedures that have been agreed to; that, subject to confidentiality provisions, they disclose relevant information to allow the negotiations to be informed; that they state their position on various issues; that they explain their position on issues; that they consider and respond to proposals made by the other side; and, of course, that they adhere to commitments given to the other negotiating party as to how they would progress matters. They are all important issues.

We also propose in our amendments that a requirement be included that the parties dedicate sufficient resources and personnel to ensure that genuine bargaining occurs. From the point of view of the employer, that is obvious. Indeed, from the point of view of an industry-wide approach, clearly just having a scattergun approach without the capacity for unions to even send officers to a particular enterprise would not be, in our view, genuine bargaining because of the inability to achieve an agreement with the resources that are applied. We also propose giving the commission powers to ensure that a negotiating party negotiates with another party and that they do so in good faith, and to make orders in respect of the efficient conduct of those negotiations.
I will explain these amendments during the consideration in detail stage of the bill, but at this stage I wish to move a second reading amendment. I move:

motion.para: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not denying the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) unreasonably emasculating the powers of the AIRC to resolve industrial disputes in the interests of the parties;
(2) interfering with the AIRC's discretion to deal with industrial disputes in the most appropriate way; and
(3) failing to put forward constructive proposals to enable the Commission to direct parties to bargain in good faith'.

speech.para: The emphasis is against the blocking approach that this government is taking because of its ideological position. Instead, we propose an empowering approach where the commission is actually given powers to get amongst the procedures and to use its expertise to assist and facilitate the parties in reaching an agreement in respect of the particular enterprise concerned. Clearly, the commission has expertise, and it should be recognised as having a legitimate role, which this government is not doing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Hawker)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—It is my pleasure this evening to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Genuine Bargaining) Bill 2002. This bill sets out to address the threat to jobs in this country caused by pattern bargaining campaigns instituted generally by militant rogue unions. For this reason there need to be better guidelines and more direction placed in this legislation so that the sort of practice where workers are affected to the extent that they are through the campaigns of these unions today cannot continue.

speech.para: Every time I get on my feet in an industrial relations exercise, I must reiterate that the Labor Party does not stand for the workers; it stands for the elite and the vested interests of its party. It does not represent the workers of this country; it uses them as fodder for its own special interests. It is not interested in the general good of the workers in this country. If it were it would be making sure that, for the greater good of workers in this country, workers were paid more. In trying to take away enterprise bargaining from individual workers in the work force it is trying to take away just that—enterprise, where you can actually do better for yourself.

Let us put this in context and make the linkages which must always be made in case people in the great wide expanses out there do not understand the connection. As we know, the unions have at least 60 per cent control over the preselections of the members of the Labor Party who are placed in this House. Yet, as reported in the Australian the other day, only something like 19 per cent of people in this country are members of a union. In 1986, 46 per cent of the work force belonged to a union. You have to ask yourself: why has this fallen so dramatically between 1986 and 2002? It is because they have done such a poor job of representing the workers. They have done such a poor job of representing the workers that the workers themselves have said, `We don't need this; we can do better on our own. The coalition government has given us some tools to get a better deal for ourselves, so this is what we intend to do.' So they seek enterprise bargaining in their individual workplace agreements.

The Labor Party do not want this, and their union mates do not want this either. They tell Labor members, `We put you here, and you had better make sure we get our agenda up or else you won't stay—we will replace you with somebody more compliant.' I will not go much further into the backgrounds and work histories of members in this House, but we do know that the vast majority of them have worked in a union organisation. So at the end of the day, this is all about the unions saying to their people in this House, who they control, `You make sure this doesn't happen, because if it does we will lose control of the work force and we do not want that to happen.' In a recent Internet survey, out of the 19 per cent of people in the work force who are members of a union today, 51 per cent of the respondents said that they would not vote Labor in any case. Here we see a further delusion about the sort of representation these people are trying to bring to the House.

I will now address some of the detail of this bill. Genuine bargaining to get a better deal really should happen in the work force, but it is not happening. This is because the union hierarchy in this country, with the support of the Labor Party, do not want people going off on little sorties of their own, because that would ultimately lead to the unions not being able to control the work force. During discussion of a previous bill here recently, the member for Brisbane interjected something like, `What are you talking about? You say only 19 per cent of the people in the work force are members of a union. How can that stop a country? How can that hold anyone up?' It can do so very easily, as we have seen just recently. If you stop the steel components going to a car yard, or stop the flight controllers at Sydney airport or other airports, you stop the whole industry. So let us not be fooled about what a small component of the work force can do to the whole work force. This is about levering upaction so that the Labor Party can get their own way on these bills.

The main parts of this bill will force unions to try to reach genuine agreements with employers before they can strike—and particularly before they can start pattern bargainingexercises—and will help the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to order cooling-off periods where there is a protracted dispute. What is the matter with legislation that tries to get people to produce better outcomes—that tries to get people to genuinely reach agreement? The unions that oppose this bill forget that many people in the work force now are subcontractors employing one or two people or are self-employed. If these people go to a work site and negotiate a better deal because they are more productive and have the opportunity to work longer hours without all the conditions that go with that just to get the job done and make sure that at the end of the day they can move on to their next job or get a success fee for having finished earlier, what is the matter with that? They are getting a better deal.

A militant union, the CFMEU, is out of control in the building industry in Perth. It is run by the great Kevin Reynolds,who said at the weekend that the member for Hotham was the worst opposition leader that he had seen. By the way—this is just an aside, but it should be widely known—Laurie Oakes on the morning show the other day said that this is the worst opposition he has seen in 40 years. What is the matter with trying to get a better deal for individuals in the work force? Strikes do cost jobs. The CFMEU—the rogue union in Perth—and Joe McDonald quite willingly say, `We are militant and we will take any measures we can to get our way.'

The Cole royal commissionin Perth recently found some very bad workplaces in terms of intimidation, threats and lock-outs—`no ticket, no start'. These sorts of leverage arrangements used by unions to try to get their own way on work sites in the building industry are a disgrace. The opposition would say, `The Industrial Relations Commission can address all this.' But we have seen recently that they do not. The Industrial Relations Commission has put orders on companies—for example, in the recent strike by the car workers which included BHP moving steel from its yards—and the unions have ignored the commission. They have blatantly thumbed their noses at the Industrial Relations Commission and said, `We are not going to follow your directive. You can fine us if you like et cetera.' Basically they have given the middle-finger salute, which is just inappropriate in these circumstances. That is how weak and ineffectual the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has become. Even though it could take measures to enforce orders, it does not.

We are saying that there need to be stronger legislation and stronger measures to ensure that the amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 go ahead. The bill will guide the IRC when it considers whether a party is genuinely trying to reach agreement with other negotiating parties, particularly in cases involving, as I have said, pattern bargaining. The bill will also add to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and empower the commission to make orders preventing the initiation of a new bargaining period or attaching conditions to any such bargaining period where a bargaining period has been withdrawn. In addition, the amendment will empower the commission to order cooling-off periods in respect of protected industrial action to facilitate resolution of issues in dispute. That is what the bill aims to achieve.

The Australian Labor Party cannot deny that when they were last in government they limited the right to strike. Strikes were intended as a means of last resort to reinforce a genuine claim for wages and working conditions—one thing in government, another thing in opposition. I thought the flip-flop Mr Beazley had gone, but no, we are back; we are being opportunistic. As is described here on a daily basis, we have cheapjack opportunism just for the sake of opposing. We have seen that with a raft of bills, whether they relate to pharmaceutical benefits or disability services. The public are getting sick of it. Out in the electorate they say to me: `What are these people doing? They didn't win the last election. They don't want to see this country go forward, be more productive and work more efficiently. They're just going to oppose you at every step of the way. They really don't care about the consequences. In this case they really don't care about the workers, because if they did they would allow them to have individual workplace agreements whereby they can bargain for a better deal.'

The unions of this country are hell-bent on extending the right to strike, and that is why the Australian Council of Trade Unions opposes this bill. I do not disagree with the right to strike in the right circumstances, but the right to strike in relation to a genuine bargaining exercise involves their putting on bogus strikes to win a political and philosophical argument under the guise of things like safety. How many times do you hear them argue a case and then, when they are not winning, suddenly say: `It's a safety issue now; everybody out the gate and off the site. We're not winning and we'll find some way of arguing a safety issue.' For example, recently in Perth, in my home state, it was very coincidental that three or four cranes on work sites in the CBD suddenly toppled over. The Australian Labor Party, through the unions, were saying: `Shock, horror! Look at all this! What's going on? These crane companies are a disgrace. There is a safety problem here. The crane drivers are a problem.' Guess what happened? When it was realised that a union front trained the crane drivers, they suddenly stopped. That was one of the bogus safety exercises that they went through to win a political point on the work site.

The unions claim that the bill will deny workers the right to strike. It will not do so, but it will put a serious dent in the side of irresponsible campaigns like the AMWU's so-called Campaign 2000 and Campaign 2003. I heard the member for Barton say, `Look, this is terrible because this legislation really only aims at a very small percentage of ratbags in the industry.' The whole industry is basically a ratbag. It is very unproductive. We have seen investment and jobs associated with it dry up, and that is costing progress in that industry. The member for Barton says, `It is overkill because we are really hitting just a small percentage of people.' That is quite bizarre, because it is like saying, `We won't have any laws on the road now because we will only target those bad speeding drivers and the people who do not do the right thing on the road, so why not cancel most road rules because they apply only to the rotten few?' It just does not gel—it just does not have any resonance. The member for Barton is a good fellow and so on but we know that he is reluctantly in here endeavouring to hold up his end with this argument because he is one of the few opposition members who do not have a great union pedigree.

Another aspect is that the unions, particularly the AMWU, advocate pattern bargaining because it gives them control over entire industries. They do not want to control the workers they have in an industry—that is, the small percentage of people who belong to a union; they want to create pattern bargaining to control a whole industry. We now need to address the bargaining fees that unions even want to charge non-union workers. It does not apply only to registered members of a union; they want to control everyone on the work site whether or not they are union members. It is control-freak stuff. We know that the AMWU's web site declares that it is pursuing an industry-wide agreement for all manufacturing workers, not just the ones who belong to that union. We know that the great old Australian-born Dougie Cameron and Craig Johnston of the AMWU have made it clear that it is their intent to use pattern bargaining to end enterprise bargaining within the manufacturing industry. They actually want to end it. They do not want it to go any further. They cannot have a dual system or a compliance system. They want to end it totally. In fact, Craig Johnston, the chief policy officer of the Labor Party and a member of the Victorian branch of the AMWU, cannot be trusted with the sort of power the unions are seeking with the blessing of the ALP.

In the past year alone, members of this branch of the union have held out on paying a $20,000 contempt of court fine for holding illegal stop-work meetings. This fine was eventually paid by an anonymous businessman. That poor old businessman was probably blackmailed into paying it because he wanted his job finished.
